questions.text: A female patient presented with a lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An asymmetrical lesion, with an irregular border, with black/brown pigmentation points towards a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. 

Types of melanoma:

  • Lentigo maligna
  • Superficial spreading
  • Acral lentiginous
  • Nodular

Histopathology of melanoma:

  • Individual melanoma cells are larger than normal melanocytes
  • They have large nuclei with irregular contours, chromatin is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane with prominent red eosinophilic nucleoli
  • All tumors have a vertical and radial phase of growth. The appearance of melanocytes is similar in both phases. The vertical growth has is often heralded by the appearance of a nodule.
  • The possibility of metastasis correlates with the depth of invasion which is called the Breslow thickness.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing an open laparotomy. Which among the following is best as a maintenance infusion during surgery?
questions.solution:
The IV fluid of choice in the intraoperative period is crystalloid.

The rationale is that these effectively increase the plasma volume more than other fluids. Although colloids have similar effects, the potential toxicities of colloids have replaced colloids by crystalloids in most setups.

In cases of high risk cases, it is advisable to monitor the cardiac output with invasive methods for early detection of hypovolumea and hypotension. in such cases, fluid volume has to be titrated.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the OPD with bilateral swelling of lower limbs. On examination, there is elevated JVP, hepatomegaly, and ascites. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of elevated JVP, hepatomegaly and edema is suggestive of cardiac failure.

Heart failure is a complex clinical syndrome that occurs because the ventricle is unable to fill with or eject blood. The etiology of heart failure includes:

  • Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Cardiomyopathies
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • High output states, such as beriberi, thyrotoxicosis, severe anemia

Signs and symptoms of heart failure are:

Right heart failure Left heart failure
Due to congestion in the systemic circulation Due to congestion in the lungs. 

Symptoms and signs:

  • Raised JVP
  • Congestive hepatomegaly
  • Positive hepatojugular reflux
  • Ascites
  • Bilateral pitting edema 
  • Weight gain- due to edema
  • Fatigue- due to ↓pumping of blood to lungs leading to ↓oxygenation of the blood

Symptoms and signs: 

  • Dyspnea on exertion
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (characteristic of LVF)
  • Pulmonary rales 
  • Increased PCWP
  • Fatigue- due to ↓cardiac output

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and impaired memory. On examination, her BMI is 43 kg/m2, blood pressure is 170/100 mm of Hg. Her awake arterial blood gas analysis shows bicarbonate - 33 mEq/L, PaCO2 - 53 mmHg,  PaO2 - 70 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of this patient with awake high pCO2, low pO2, and BMI of 41 is obesity hypoventilation syndrome.

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) or Pickwickian syndrome is defined as the presence of awake alveolar hypoventilation in an obese individual which cannot be attributed to other conditions associated with alveolar hypoventilation.

Patients with OHS are obese and have a history of daytime hypersomnolence, loud snoring, choking during sleep fatigue, impaired concentration and memory, a small oropharynx, and a thick neck.

OHS may be associated with the following findings:

  • Elevated serum bicarbonate (>27 mEq/L)
  • Hypercapnia (PaCO2 >45 mmHg)
  • Hypoxemia (PaO2 <70 mmHg)
  • Polycythemia

Other options:

Option A: Central sleep apnea is characterized by a lack of respiratory effort during sleep, leading to recurrent pauses in breathing. It's less likely in this case due to the hypercapnia (elevated PaCO2) seen.

Option B: Narcolepsy involves excessive daytime sleepiness, sudden loss of muscle tone (cataplexy), sleep paralysis, and hallucinations during sleep onset. It doesn't typically cause elevated PaCO2.

Option D: Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) involves repeated episodes of partial or complete upper airway obstruction during sleep. While obesity is a risk factor for OSA, the arterial blood gas analysis findings are more consistent with OHS.

questions.text: A male was referred to the urology OPD for evaluation of infertility. Karyotyping analysis revealed an XXY karyotype. Which of the following statements is not true about the condition?

choices.text: Levels of follicle-stimulating hormone are reduced

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Klinefelter's syndrome. In this condition, the follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels are elevated. 

The clinical features include:

  • Eunuchoid body habitus - elongated body and long legs (increased length between the soles and the pubic bone)
  • Absence of secondary sexual characteristics - lack of body and facial hair, deep voice
  • Small atrophic testes
  • Micropenis
  • Gynecomastia
  • Lower IQ, but no mental retardation

The following hormonal variations are seen in these patients:

  • Elevated FSH
  • Elevated estradiol
  • Low testosterone
  • Insulin resistance - increased incidence of type 2 diabetes

Patients with Klinefelter syndrome are at a higher risk for:

  • Male breast cancer (20x more common than in normal males)
  • Extragonadal germ cell tumors
  • Autoimmune diseases - systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.text: A male was brought with the following injury in a gunshot incident. What is the possible range from which the weapon inflicted injury?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, based on the stellate-shaped wound seen, it seems to be a contact shot entry wound.

A contact shot entry wound on the skull typically has a stellate shape due to high-energy impact. 

  • Firearm wounds are fundamental of two main types: wounds of entry and wounds of exit. The wound of entry is the wound through which the bullet or pellets enter the body, and the wound of exit is the wound through which the bullet emerges out of the body.
  • To determine the range of firing, the following parameters are used:
    • The entry wound size and shape
    • Blast effect: Muzzle end imprint and edge eversion
    • Blackening, tattooing, singeing of hair, abrasion collar, and grease collar
    • Hair should be preserved to determine the range of firing which can be examined for carbonization/desiccation at close range, and also from lead deposition around the wound to assess the range of firing.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with complaints of bleeding gums. Blood investigations showed iron deficiency anemia.  Which of the following vitamin deficiencies do you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Dietary deficiency of vitamin C can lead to scurvy which can manifest as microcytic anemia, defective collagen synthesis, and bleeding manifestations.

Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. It is mainly required for the hydroxylation of prolyl and lysyl residues of collagen reactions. It also maintains vitamin E and many metal cofactors (eg. copper) in a reduced state. It also facilitates the absorption of iron by reducing it from a ferric to a ferrous state.

Hence, vitamin C deficiency leads to defective collagen synthesis, fragile blood vessels, and iron deficiency anemia. Other clinical features of scurvy include spongy gums, loose teeth, swollen joints, subcutaneous hemorrhage, and bone fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not included in ABCD2 scoring?
questions.solution:
History of stroke is not a factor used in the calculation of ABCD2 scoring.

The risk of stroke following transient ischemic attacks (TIA) is determined by the ABCD2 score. The components of the ABCD2 are shown in the table below

Age ≥60 years 1
<60 years 0
Blood pressure elevation when first assessed after TIA Systolic ≥ 140 mm Hg or Diastolic ≥90 mm Hg 1
Systolic <140 mm Hg and diastolic < 90 mm Hg 0
Clinical features Unilateral weakness 2
Isolated speech disturbance 1
Other  0
Duration of TIA symptoms   ≥60 minutes 2
10 to 59 minutes 1
<10 minutes 0
 Diabetes Present 1
Absent  0

 Interpretation of ABCD2 score:

  • Score 6 to 7: High two-day stroke risk
  • Score 4 to 5: Moderate two-day stroke risk
  • Score 0 to 3: Low two-day stroke risk

questions.text: Immediately post-delivery, the uterus corresponds to __ weeks of gestational age:
questions.solution:
Immediately post-delivery, the uterus corresponds to 20 weeks of gestational age.

The rate of involution of the uterus can be clinically assessed by noting the fundal height of the uterus in relation to the symphysis pubis.

Involution of the uterus occurs due to a decrease in the size of muscle fibers.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulceration?
questions.solution:
Gastroduodenoscopy is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulcer disease.

Gastroduodenoscopy helps to directly visualise the ulcer and simultaneously perform a biopsy to rule out malignancy. This makes it a better investigation compared to others.

Gastric peptic ulcers are predominantly located along the lesser curvature near the interface of the body and antrum. The most common site of peptic ulcer is the anterior wall of the proximal duodenum, within a few centimeters of the pyloric valve. 

The image below shows a peptic ulcer with a round to oval and sharply punched-out defect, and a clean mucosal margin.

Complications of peptic ulcers:

  • Bleeding - It is the most common complication of posterior duodenal ulcer.
  • Perforation - It is the most common complication of anterior duodenal ulcer and gastric ulcer.
  • Obstruction.
  • Hour-glass deformity of the stomach - Large long-standing gastric ulcers can lead to fibrosis. Fibrosis if present can cause hourglass constriction of the stomach. Barium meal shows double pouched stomach.
  • Tea-pot deformity (handbag stomach) - It is caused by cicatrization and shortening of the lesser curvature.
  • An ulcer can erode posteriorly into the pancreas and anteriorly into the liver.
  • Malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is least useful in the management of a patient with Thalamic Dejerine syndrome?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, ibuprofen, which is an analgesic (NSAID) is considered the least effective in the management of Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome.

Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome, also known as Thalamic Pain Syndrome or Central Post-Stroke Pain, is a condition characterized by severe and often chronic pain on one side of the body following damage to the thalamus in the brain, commonly due to a stroke.

Occlusion of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches results in thalamic pain syndrome. It is characterized by C/L hemi-sensory loss which starts as numbness and progresses to cause severe burning pain in the affected regions.

As the thalamus is the site for the relay of sensory information between the periphery and cortex, a lesion in the thalamus causes a miscommunication between the afferent pathway and the cortex of the brain. Pain occurs during the recovery from the thalamic infarct.

This pain responds poorly to analgesics. 

Anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine, gabapentin, or tricyclic antidepressants like amitriptyline may be beneficial.

questions.text: What nutrient deficiency is commonly associated with delayed wound healing following minor surgery?
questions.solution:
Delayed wound healing after minor surgery can be attributed to a deficiency in vitamin C.

Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, plays a crucial role in collagen synthesis, a protein that is essential for wound healing and tissue repair. Collagen provides structural support to the skin, blood vessels, and other connective tissues. A deficiency in vitamin C can lead to impaired collagen formation, weakening of blood vessels, and delayed wound healing.

Factors influencing healing:

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

Even though zinc also causes poor wound healing, Vitamin C is more commonly implicated.

questions.text: A female presented a few weeks ago to the OPD  with an itchy skin rash. She was prescribed a topical ointment that relieved the itching. However, after a few days of stopping the ointment application, she presented to the OPD again with the same complaints. The lesions are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient presented with an itchy skin rash and was most likely given topical corticosteroids. The image shows atypical lesions of tinea, which is a fungal infection. Although steroids could have provided initial relief, it is not the appropriate treatment for this condition. Therefore, the skin rash reappeared when the patient stopped using the ointment. This scenario is suggestive of tinea incognito.

  • Steroids suppress inflammation without eliminating the fungus; so the typical raised margin is diminished, scaling is lost and inflammation reduces. Hence, diagnosis becomes difficult. Once steroid dosage is decreased or stopped, scaling reappears and shows fungal mycelium.
  • Treatment: Oral terbinafine or itraconazole

Tinea corporis/ ringworm infection is caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum with lesions on the trunk and limbs. 

Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge with central resolution. Scaling is a common but not a constant finding. The diagnosis is mostly clinical. In case of doubt, skin scrapings from site of lesion examined under a microscope may show fungal mycelium.

Pharmacological treatment of fungal Tinea infection is :

Localized disease, recent onset

  • Topical terbinafine twice daily for 2 weeks
  • Topical azole once or twice daily for 2–4 weeks

Widespread disease

  • First-line:
    Oral terbinafine 250 mg/day 2–3 weeks
    Oral Itraconazole 100 mg/day 2–4 weeks
  • Second line:
    Oral Griseofulvin 1 g/day for 4 weeks

questions.text: A young boy presented with a bluish-red cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. On examination, it showed fluctuation and transillumination. It was initially 1.5 cm, and progressed to 5 cm in the last few months. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are suggestive of a ranula.

Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocal sacs of a frog.

It is of two types:

  • Oral ranula - It is a benign cystic lesion formed by extravasation of mucus, involving the sublingual gland. Clinically present as cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. On examination fluctuation test and transillumination test is positive. It is conservatively managed by marsupialization. Definitive management is the excision of the cyst. Some may resolve spontaneously.
  • Cervical or plunging ranula- is a rare type of retention cyst arising from the sublingual gland. The mucous passes through the mylohyoid muscle diaphragm to enter the neck. Clinically present as intraoral and cervical swelling. Diagnosis is made by USG or MRI. Management includes excision of the sublingual gland + aspiration of saliva out of the sac.

Other options:

Options A: Ectopic thyroid tissue is a developmental defect of the thyroid gland and is frequently found along the course of the thyroglossal duct. Lingual thyroid is the most common presentation of ectopic thyroid (shown below).

Option B: Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling. 

Option C: Ludwig's angina is a brawny swelling of the submandibular region that is caused by streptococcal infection. The infection tracks down to the mylohyoid muscle causing inflammation that displaces the tongue leading to dysphagia and painful airway obstruction. Management is by antibiotic therapy and decompression of the floor of the mouth by incising mylohyoid muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission?

choices.text: Setting up of Health and Wellness centres
Health insurance coverage upto Rs 10 lakh per family per year
Treatment to all preexisting diseases are covered
Age appropriate health promotion at schools

questions.solution:
The health insurance coverage under Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission is upto 5 lakh per family per year

The primary aim of the Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission is to build a comprehensive need-based health care service. 

Components: The target of the two initiatives mentioned below is to build a New India 2022.

  • Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- These centers will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services.
  • The second component is the National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) which provides health protection coverage to poor and vulnerable families. The Health and Wellness Centres will play a critical role in creating awareness about AB-NHPM, screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow-up of hospitalization cases among others.
  • School health programs including age-appropriate health promotion, screening, supplementation of iron and folic acid tablets, health administration via health centres.

Benefits:

  • The government provides health insurance coverage of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • All families listed in the SECC database as per the defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members.
  • Priority to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empaneled private hospitals in times of need.
  • Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances to a 24X7 helpline number - 14555

questions.text: An elderly male patient presents with persistent fatigue and anemia. Given his clinical profile, what is the recommended screening protocol for colon cancer in this patient?

choices.text: Fecal occult blood testing every 2 years

questions.solution:
Anemia and fatigue in an elderly patient can be indicative of gastrointestinal bleeding, possibly from colorectal cancer, the most appropriate protocol for screening for colon cancer is a colonoscopy every 10 years.

Current ACS guidelines advocate screening the average-risk population for colorectal carcinoma beginning at age 50 years. Screening recommendations include the following:

  1. Annual faecal occult blood test (FOBT), or
  2. Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or
  3. FOBT and flexible sigmoidoscopy in combination every 5 years, or
  4. Air-contrast barium enema every 5 years, or
  5. Colonoscopy every 10 years.

A positive FOBT should be followed by a colonoscopy.

Patients with other risk factors (considered a high-risk population) should be screened earlier and more frequently, as shown below:

Population Initial age Recommendation
Familial colorectal cancer first-degree relative 40 years of age or 10 years before the age of the youngest affected relative (whichever is earlier) Colonoscopy every 5 years
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis) At diagnosis; then 8 years after diagnosis Colonoscopy with multiple biopsies every 1–2 years
Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) 10–12 years of age Annual flexible sigmoidoscopy
Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) 20–25 years of age Colonoscopy every 1–2 years

For individuals at average risk of colon cancer, current guidelines recommend colonoscopy as the gold standard for screening. Colonoscopy allows direct visualization of the entire colon and is effective at detecting both polyps and cancers. Given the patient's age, symptoms of anemia, and potential risk factors, a colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate protocol for colorectal cancer screening.

questions.text: A post-mortem cooling graph is plotted. What is the ideal shape of this graph?
questions.solution:
The graph plotted during post-mortem cooling is ideally sigmoid or inverted S-shaped. 

Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. Up to the first hour, a temperature plateau may be seen due to the heat generated by residual metabolic activities of dying tissues. This is followed by a linear rate of cooling over the next 12 to 16 hours. The temperature rarely reaches the ambient temperature, most likely due to bacterial action with decomposition setting in.

questions.text: After receiving a complaint from a security guard, the police recovered a beheaded skull bone near a park. During the investigation, the police suspected that it could be that of a known missing person. The missing person's relatives were called in to confirm the identity. Which of the following techniques can be used to figure out a person's identity using the beheaded skull bone and photograph of the person?
questions.solution:
The technique used to figure out a person's identity using the beheaded skull bone and photograph of the person is superimposition. The superimposition technique is applied to the skull to determine whether it belongs to the person in the photograph.

The following points can be used for comparisons such as the eyes, nasion, prosthion, zygomas, lower border of the nose, supraorbital ridges, lower border of the zygomas, angle of the jaw, external auditory meatus, teeth and the lower border of the upper jaw.

Other options:

Option B: Anthropometry is based on the principle that the skeletal dimensions do not change after the age of 21 years and the variation in the size of the different parts to one another. Descriptive data such as the color of the hair, eyes, complexion, and body marks are recorded. Body measurements are estimated such as height, anteroposterior diameter of head and trunk, the span of outstretched arms, the length of the left middle finger, left little finger, left forearm, left foot, length, and breadth of right ear, and color of left iris from the photographs. 

Option C: DNA fingerprinting for forensic analysis is done to detect DNA from small amounts of samples from the crime scene. DNA fingerprinting uses restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLPs) or Polymerase chain reaction(PCR) to identify a person's unique pattern of DNA. 

Option D: Cheiloscopy is also known as lip printing. Here, the fissures and grooves on the lip characteristic of a person are examined.

questions.text: A female patient presented with a 4 x 3 cm lump over the right breast. On examination, Peau d'orange appearance can be noted. What is the tumor staging in this patient?
questions.solution:
Skin involvement over the breast- peau d'orange appearance classifies this as stage T4b.

Peau d'orange appearance is due to the blockage of subcuticular lymphatics. The resultant edema deepens the mouth of the sweat glands and hair follicles giving rise to the typical orange peel appearance. 

This given clinical scenario in this woman with peau d’orange of the breast suggests her staging is T4b. Tumor of any size with overlying skin involvement (Peau d'orange appearance) classifies it as stage T4b.

The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin. The dermal lymphatic blockade gives rise to edema in the breast. The sweat glands and hair follicles get buried due to the edema resulting in a typical orange peel appearance. Infiltration of the ligaments of Cooper results in dimpling of the skin. Infiltration of the lactiferous glands gives rise to retraction of the nipple. Spread into the chest wall results in fixation of the breast into the chest wall. This leads to restricted mobility of the breast

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: A 46-year old lady is being evaluated for abnormal uterine bleeding by a dilatation and curettage procedure. The following instruments are placed on a table in the minor operating theatre. Which of the following instruments will be used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Among the given instruments 1, 2, and 3 - Sim's uterine curette, Hegar's dilators, and Simpson's uterine sound are used for dilatation and curettage (D&C).

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sim’s speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other.
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar's dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sim's curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette

Other options: 

Karman's cannula: It is used for menstrual regulation. 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A patient is obsessed with keeping herself clean. She washes her hands multiple times and is yet never satisfied with her cleanliness. She even refuses to go out because she is afraid of getting contaminated. Which phase of development are these personality traits related to?
questions.solution:
The patient has traits of obsession and rigidity which point to a diagnosis of OCD. These are due to fixation in the anal stage of development.

Sigmund Freud proposed five stages of psychosocial development and stated that when the development of a child gets arrested at one stage, called fixation, it results in psychiatric disorders.

The phases are:

Phase of sexual development

Disorders resulting from fixation in this phase

Oral phase

(birth- 1.5 years)

Learning how to eat.

The mouth is the site of pleasure.

Alcohol dependence or drug dependence

Schizophrenia

Severe mood disorders

Dependent personality disorder

Anal phase

(1.5-3 years)

Toilet training.

The site of pleasure is the anal region.

OCD

Phallic/Oedipal phase

(3-5 years)

Site of pleasure is the genital region.

Oedipus/Electra complex, which is the primary cause of hysteria.

Also, castration anxiety in boys and penis envy in girls.

Latency phase

(5-12 years)

Neurotic disorder

Genital phase

sexual orientation

(>12 years)

Neurotic disorder

questions.text: Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis  is done in many countries to protect the home population. What form of prevention is this?
questions.solution:
Screening of immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis is an example of Prospective screening, which is a form of primary prevention.   

Prospective screening is done for the benefit of others, who have not gotten the disease. This is done so that the disease is controlled and not spread. Thus, it is a form of primary prevention. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection, and people are screened for their own benefits of early diagnosis of diseases existing in them. This is a form of secondary prevention. e.g., neonatal screening for hypothyroidism, pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.

questions.text: A male patient presented with swelling in his lower limb. The clinical image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis.

Lymphatic filariasis occurs due to the transmission of W.bancrofti by the bite of Culex mosquitoes. The third stage larval forms from the mosquito enter the lymphatics and lymph nodes where they develop into adult worms. The adult worms become sexually mature and mate to release microfilariae which enter the peripheral circulation.

The disease initially causes acute attacks of lymphangitis and lymphadenitis. Early treatment may even cure the disease. The lymphedema may gradually worsen and get associated with the thickening of the skin and fibrosis of lymph vessels or blockage by adult worms. Hydrocele is another common manifestation that occurs due to lymphatic obstruction.

Microfilaria can be demonstrated in blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid, however, peripheral blood is the preferred choice. The examination of a thick and thin blood smear stained with Giemsa stain shows the microfilaria. Other methods are by examining the unstained blood under a microscope for the actively motile microfilariae and by acridine orange-microhematocrit tube technique.

The best time to collect the blood samples is at night, between 10 pm and 4 am as they are nocturnally periodic.

DEC provocation test: In this test, a small dose of DEC is given 20-50 minutes before sample collection so that the microfilaria appears in the blood even during the daytime. 

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

Other Options:

  • Deep Vein Thrombosis is a condition in which a blood clot forms in a deep vein, usually in the legs. It can cause pain, swelling, and warmth in the affected area, but it doesn't lead to the type of severe swelling and disfigurement seen in the image.
  • Edems refers to the accumulation of fluid in the body's tissues, leading to swelling. While edema can cause swelling, it doesn't typically cause the extreme and localized swelling associated with lymphatic filariasis.
  • Mansonelliasis is a disease caused by another type of parasitic worm called Mansonella. It can lead to symptoms such as skin rashes, joint pain, and fever, but it doesn't typically result in the severe and localized swelling seen in the image.

questions.text: Which of the following solutions is recommended as the diluent for the BCG vaccine ?
questions.solution:
Normal saline is recommended as the diluent for the BCG vaccine as distilled water is an irritant.

questions.text: A patient presents with a pansystolic murmur and features of carditis. Echocardiography showed mitral regurgitation.Which of the following is the most common manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of mitral regurgitation is most commonly seen in rheumatic heart disease. The most common manifestation of this disease is arthritis

Major manifestations of rheumatic fever are:

  • Migratory polyarthritis of the large joints 
  • Pancarditis (myocarditis, pericarditis, or endocarditis)
  • Subcutaneous nodules (typically on extensor surfaces of extremities)
  • Erythema marginatum, an irregular circinate skin rash 
  • Sydenham chorea, a neurologic disorder with involuntary rapid movements

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about triage, according to the internationally accepted four-color-coded system?

choices.text: Yellow - Significant injuries, hemodynamically stable patients, required monitoring
Green - Patients in life threatening conditions

questions.solution:
The yellow color tag is given for the patients who have significant injuries but are hemodynamically stable, and need monitoring. They are the medium priority patients.

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment.

It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

The internationally accepted four-color coded system is commonly used. It includes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority) (option A).

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)(option C).

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)(option D).

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)(option B).

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden irresistible urges to do things that come to his mind. Which of the following best describes this symptom?
questions.solution:
The sudden irresistible urge to do things is called impulse.

They arise from intrusive thoughts the person has. These uncontrollable impulses seem rewarding to the subject. The person aims for immediate gratification and relief by just performing the act than from the after-effects. If the impulsive action has consequences in the long term, they tend to neglect these consequences. Often after acting on the impulse, the subject feels remorse and guilt. This in turn can lead to marked distress in the personal, family, social, and educational spheres.

Repeated failure to resist an impulse is the characteristic feature of impulse control disorder. They include

  1. Pyromania
  2. Kleptomania 
  3. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder
  4. Intermittent explosive disorder

 Option a: hallucination refers to a disorder of perception where there is perception without any stimuli.

Option b: illusion is another disorder of perception where a stimulus is perceived as something different,

Option c: delusion refers to false unshakable believes that arent in line with the socioeconomic background of the subject.

questions.text: A 38 year old male patient presented with complaints of paranasal sinus pain and bloody nasal discharge for the past few days. He also has a previous history of hemoptysis and hematuria. Imaging revealed multiple, bilateral, nodular cavitary infiltrates. Which of the following antibodies would be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of this patient suggest granulomatosis with polyangitis which is positive for anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) in 90% of patients. Granulomatosis polyangitis has a very high specificity for anti-proteinase 3 ANCA.

Granulomatosis polyangitis is an autoimmune small vessel vasculitis syndrome characterized by granulomatous vasculitits of the upper and lower respiratory tracts with glomerulonephritis. Incidence is equal in bot males and females and the mean age of onset is 40 years.

Histopathologic hallmarks are necrotising vasculitis of small arteries and veins with granuloma formation. 

Upper respiratory tract features : Paranasal sinus pain & discharge and purulent/ bloody nasal discharge. Patient may or may not develop mucosal ulceration leading to septal perforation and saddle nose deformity.

Lower respiratory tract features : Cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, chest comfort, endobronchial disease leading to atelectasis. Lung involvement appears as multiple, bilateral, nodular cavitary infiltrates. Lung biopsy will reveal necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis.

Renal involvement : Renal involvement progresses from focal segemental glomerulitis to rapidly progressive crescentic glomerulonephritis. But granulomas are rare in renal biopsy. Mild glomerulitis with proteinuria, hematuria and red blood cell casts.

May also involve the eyes, skin, heart and brain.

Laboratory findings : Elevated C-reactive protein and/or erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Positive antiproteinase 3 ANCA. 

Treatment : 2 phases, induction and maintainence phases. Glucocorticoids + immunosuppressive agent
Severe disease : Induced by rituximab or cyclophosphamide.
Remission maintainence : Rituximab/ azathioprine/ methotrexate/ mycophenolate mofetil.
Limited only to sinonasal tissues : Trimethoprim-Sulfomethoxazolemmay be tried.

Other options :

  • Option B & C. ANA and Anti-histone antibodies are more specific to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Option D. Anti-Jo 1 antibodies are specific to inflammatory myopathies.

Related Pearl: Autoantibodies Seen in Autoimmune Diseases
