questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the following clinical finding seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows bilateral periorbital ecchymoses, which is called the panda sign, and it is seen in anterior cranial fossa fractures. It is also known as panda eyes/raccoon eyes.

Anterior cranial fossa fracture occurs due to direct impact. It is a contrecoup injury that occurs when there is a direct blow to the chin (in boxing). The impact is transmitted to the maxilla and base of the skull and results in a contrecoup fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid. It presents with CSF rhinorrhea and periorbital hematoma or raccoon eyes and the image is shown below. 

The pooling of blood surrounding the eyes is most commonly associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. This finding is typically not present during the initial evaluation and is delayed by 1 to 3 days. If bilateral, this finding is highly predictive of a basilar skull fracture.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts Ritgen’s manoeuvre, a technique used during the second stage of labor to assist in the controlled delivery of the fetal head, reducing the risk of perineal tears and trauma.

Steps in Ritgen’s Maneuver:

  • The right hand is draped with a sterile towel.
  • The fingers of the right hand pressing posterior to the rectum exerts upward pressure to the chin and extends the head. The extension of the head prevents the head from slipping back in between the contractions.
  • The left hand placed over the occiput exerts a downward counterpressure to prevent the rapid extension of the head
  • The ritgen’s manoeuvre thus helps in the controlled delivery of the head of the fetus.

Other options:

Option B: Pinard’s manoeuvre is used to facilitate the delivery of legs in case of frank breech presentation.

Option C: Lovset’s manoeuvre is used to facilitate the delivery of arms in breech presentation.

Option D: In Zavanelli maneuver is an obstetric procedure used as a last-resort technique during shoulder dystocia when other manoeuvres fail to deliver the baby vaginally. The fetal head is rotated to the pre-restitution position and pushed back into the pelvis to perform an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is assessing an outbreak of acute diarrhoeal disease in a region. He wants to predict the virulence of the causative agent. Which of the following parameters will he use for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is used in this scenario as it is the most useful parameter to predict the virulence of an acute illness. It represents the killing power of disease.

Note: Case fatality rate is an incidence proportion and not a true rate as no time interval is used for its calculation.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with brown-colored urine, flank pain, and fatigue for the last 3 days. He has 2+ proteinuria with >20 red cells/HPF and dysmorphic red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child presenting with acute onset (3 days) flank pain, cola-colored urine, and mild to moderate proteinuria is suggestive of a nephritic syndrome picture. The only disease which causes this out of the given options is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

PSGN is primarily caused by group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infections in children aged 5 to 12 years. It is caused by immune complexes containing streptococcal antigens (M protein of cell wall) and specific antibodies. PSGN typically manifests as an acute nephritic syndrome, appearing either 1 to 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma. The severity of kidney involvement can vary, ranging from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria with normal renal function to gross hematuria with acute renal failure. Edema, hypertension, and oliguria may be present depending on the extent of renal involvement.

Laboratory findings commonly include a significant decrease in serum C3 levels during the acute phase, with values returning to normal within 6 to 8 weeks. To confirm the diagnosis, evidence of a preceding streptococcal infection is necessary. The antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer often increases following pharyngitis, while the anti-deoxyribonuclease B level is a reliable indicator of cutaneous streptococcal infection.

Light microscopic examination reveals enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial and endothelial proliferation, as well as leukocyte infiltration. Immunofluorescence analysis demonstrates granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and in the mesangium. Electron microscopy primarily shows subepithelial humps, with subendothelial deposits observed in early stages of the disease.

Managing the acute effects of renal insufficiency (sodium restriction and diuretics) and hypertension is the mainstay. Antibiotic therapy with a 10-day course of penicillin is recommended to limit the spread of nephritogenic pathogens. But antibiotics do not alter the natural course of PSGN. Complete resolution of the hematuria and proteinuria in the majority of children occurs within 3–6 weeks of the onset of nephritis but 3–10% of children may have persistent microscopic hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, or hypertension.

Below is the image showing light microscopy findings of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis:

questions.text: A deceased male was posted for a ​post-mortem examination. His relatives reported that he had a tattoo over his skin, which was not found during the autopsy. Which of the following would you examine to determine the absence of his tattoo?
questions.solution:
The lymph nodes should be examined in this case.

Some amount of material or dye used for creating tattoo marks is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. 

A faded tattoo mark can be visualized by:
  • Ultraviolet light
  • Infrared photography
  • Rubbing the part and examining it with a magnifying lens

In decomposed bodies, the tattoo marks can be visualized by removing the epidermis with a moist cloth. The lymph nodes near a tattoo mark also show a deposit of the pigment.

Hence in cases where a tattoo mark has disappeared naturally or has been removed, the lymph nodes must be examined before making any conclusions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hyper-estrogenic condition?
questions.solution:
Low body mass index (BMI) is not a hyper-estrogenic condition. In fact, low BMI can lead to decreased estrogen levels, as body fat plays a role in estrogen production.

Hyper-estrogenic conditions refer to conditions where there is an excessive level of estrogen in the body.

Estrogen is a hormone that plays a key role in the development of female sexual characteristics and the regulation of the menstrual cycle. 

Other options:

  • Some specific subtypes of ovarian tumors, such as Granulosa Cell Tumors and Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumors, can produce excess estrogen, leading to hyper-estrogenic effects. However, the majority of ovarian cancers are not typically associated with hyper-estrogenic conditions.
  • Tamoxifen is a medication often used in the treatment of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. It acts as a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), blocking estrogen receptors. It acts as an estrogen antagonist in the breast and an estrogen agonist in the endometrium.
  • Endometriosis involves the growth of tissue similar to the lining of the uterus (endometrium) outside the uterus. It's often associated with estrogen, as estrogen can stimulate the growth of endometrial tissue.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with difficulty in breathing and dizziness. He has been undergoing treatment for lung cancer. On examination, breath sounds were reduced over the left inferior-scapular region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of dyspnea, dizziness, and reduced breath sounds over the left inferior-scapular region in a patient with lung cancer is suggestive of pleural effusion.

Pleural effusion refers to the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space due to

  • Excess fluid formation from the interstitial spaces of the lung, parietal pleura, or peritoneal cavity.
  • Decreased fluid removal by the lymphatics.

Pleural effusion may present with dyspnea, pleuritic pain, dry cough, and associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, edema, and ascites depending on the etiology. On examination, there may be tachypnea, dullness on percussion and decreased/absent breath sounds at the base(s).

The etiology of pleural effusion can be of two types:

  • Exudative: disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage because of local factors. Examples include malignancy, infections, and pulmonary embolism.
  • Transudative: disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage due to systemic factors. Examples include congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome.

Light’s criteria can be used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

  1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum. 

Recommended tests for all diagnostic thoracocentesis include:

  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and protein
  • Microscopy and culture
  • Cytology and differential count
  • Glucose, pH, triglycerides, amylase, haematocrit, AFB culture and PCR can be done if a particular etiology is suspected.

Other options:

  1. Constrictive pericarditis: Symptoms may include swelling in the legs, fatigue, and discomfort, but it's not directly associated with reduced breath sounds or localized findings on lung examination.

  2. Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output. The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade are Beck's triad, which consists of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure.

  3. Pneumothorax: It can cause sudden, sharp chest pain and difficulty breathing, but it often presents with hyper-resonant percussion (tapping on the chest) and decreased breath sounds on the affected side.

questions.text: Which of the following can not be used for emergency contraception?

choices.text: LNG 0.75 mg single dose in 72 hours

questions.solution:
LNG 0.75 mg single dose in 72 hours would not be enough for emergency contraception. Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg, i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg, can be used as a single-dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. Alternatively, one tablet of LNG 0.75 mg can be followed by another tablet 12 hours later. The tablets can be offered for up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in the interval between coitus and drug intake.

Advantages of LNG:

  • It does not contain estrogen and therefore precludes the associated side effects.
  • It can be used in hypertensive, cardiac, and diabetic patients.
  • It is suitable for lactating women.
  • It can be given up to 120 hours after unprotected intercourse.
  • It can be given as a single-dose therapy. 

Other options:

  • Ulipristal acetate 30 mg single dose is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. It can be taken up to 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. Side effects include headache, nausea, and mood changes.
  • Centchroman is effective only if taken within 24 hours of unprotected sexual intercourse. 60 mg tablet taken twice in 24 hours can be effective in preventing implantation in 99% of women.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with jerky movements of her extremities for 1 week. She has typical hand movements, which are shown in the image below. She also complains of pain in multiple joints. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals jaundice. Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with jaundice along with the clip showing a wing beating tremor is suggestive of Wilson's disease with decompensation. The gold standard for diagnosis is liver biopsy.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing-beating tremor 
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens, resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease, but not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state; therefore the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Diagnosis:

  • Presence of KF rings
  • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
  • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy - Gold standard
  • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

Treatment: Recommended anti copper Drugs for Wilson's Disease

Disease Status First Choice Second Choice
Initial    

Hepatitis or Cirrhosis without decompensation

 Zinc Trientine
Hepatic decompensation    
Mild Trientine and Zinc Penicillamine and Zinc
Moderate Trientine and Zinc Hepatic transplantation
Severe Hepatic Transplantation Trientine and Zinc
Initial neurological/Psychiatric Tetrathiomolybdate and Zinc Zinc
Maintenance Zinc Trientine
Presymptomatic Zinc Trientine

questions.text: An elderly male patient who is a known case of COPD, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus visits the OPD to review his medications. Which of the following criteria should be followed by the physician during the review?
questions.solution:
Beer's criteria is widely used for reducing the use of potentially inappropriate medications and polypharmacy in the geriatric population.

American Geriatric Society came up with Beer's criteria to review potentially inappropriate medications and avoid polypharmacy and deprescribe irrational medications due to the increased adverse effects of many drugs in the geriatric age group. This includes:

  • Explicit list of drugs that should be avoided in older adults
  • Drugs that should be avoided or be used at lower doses in patients with reduced kidney function
  • Specific drug-disease and drug-drug interactions that are known to be harmful in older adults

Long-acting benzodiazepines, proton pump inhibitors, antipsychotics, aspirin, dipyridamole, propoxyphene, and amitriptyline were among the most frequently prescribed inappropriate medications.

Medications like glimepiride, rivaroxaban, tramadol, and certain antipsychotic medications in patients with Parkinson's disease are recently added to the use-with-caution list.

Other options:

  • The Light's Criteria is used to differentiate between different causes of pleural effusions (transudative vs exudative).
  • The Jones Criteria is used for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. 
  • The Duke's Criteria is used for the diagnosis of Infective Endocarditis (IE)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about radiotherapy?

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Vomiting is a late adverse reaction
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Radiation-induced skin changes is a reversible adverse effect

questions.solution:
The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance from the source of radiation. This is known as the inverse square law in radiotherapy.

Inverse square law - the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance from the source of radiation. This principle is unsuitable for large tumors and has potential risks of radiation exposure to medical staff.

Other options: 

Option B: Vomiting can be an acute (early) adverse reaction to radiation therapy, occurring shortly after treatment.

Option C: Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells.

Option D: Not all the adverse effects of radiation therapy are reversible. Some of the adverse effects of radiation therapy, such as fibrosis, radiation-induced skin changes, late radiation enteritis, etc are irreversible.

questions.text: An intern is observing the procedure of thoracocentesis. What is the site of needle insertion in this procedure?
questions.solution:
The correct site for needle insertion during thoracentesis is usually at the upper border of the lower rib. This location helps to prevent any injury to the intercostal nerve and vessels.

For thoracocentesis, a posterior approach is preferred. The patient should sit on the edge of the bed, leaning forward with the arms abducted onto a pillow on a bedside stand. The patient might have severe dyspnea, so it is important to assess whether they can maintain this position for 10 minutes before performing the procedure. The entry site for the thoracocentesis is at the superior aspect of the rib.

This prevents any injury to the intercostal nerve and vessels. 

While maintaining gentle negative pressure, the needle should be slowly advanced into the pleural space. If a diagnostic tap is being performed, 30-50 mL of fluid will be adequate. If a therapeutic thoracocentesis is being performed, a maximum of 1 liter of pleural fluid should be withdrawn at a given time. Withdrawal of quantities more than this can cause re-expansion pulmonary edema. A chest radiograph should be obtained post-procedure to evaluate for a pneumothorax. The patient should be instructed to inform the doctors if new shortness of breath develops.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with halitosis, dysphagia, and regurgitation of food. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis​?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of halitosis and regurgitation in an elderly man suggests a diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum or Pulsion pseudodiverticulum. 

Zenker diverticulum, or cricopharyngeal achalasia/pharyngeal pouch, is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum (false diverticula occurring due to motor disorder causing increased intraluminal pressure). It results from the herniation of mucosa and submucosa through Killian's triangle (dehiscence of Killian).

Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the cricopharyngeus's transverse fibers and the thyropharyngeus's oblique fibers (shown below).

 

It is usually seen in the seventh decade of life and is thought to occur due to loss of muscle tone and elasticity causing incomplete relaxation. The impaired relaxation and spasms of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing results in increased pressure within the distal pharynx and the development of Zenker's diverticulum.

Patients complain of dysphagia, halitosis, recurrent regurgitation, and respiratory infections. The most serious complications are aspiration pneumonia and lung abscess.

Diagnosis is by barium swallow studies and video laryngoscopy. The gold standard of treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. The transoral endoscopic approach is known as the Dohlman procedure in which the common wall between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus is ablated using laser, electrocautery, or stapler devices. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size. Lesions less than 2 cm are managed with myotomy. A sac more than 5 cm is usually excised.

Other options:

Option A: Cancer esophagus also presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food, but halitosis is more classically seen with Zenker's diverticulum. The patient would also have weight loss, anorexia and other cancer related symptoms.

Option B: Achalasia is a type of esophageal motility disorder and a premalignant condition that occurs due to hypertension of the lower esophageal sphincter and thereby failure to relax. The classic triad of presentation is dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. Esophagogram shows the classic bird beak appearance (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing). 

Option D: GERD also presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food, but halitosis is not seen in GERD, it is more classic of Zenker's diverticulum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, diabetic patient presented with acute onset fever and chills. She also complains of pain in the right flank area. Urine examination revealed plenty of leukocytes with glycosuria. A CT scan of the abdomen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows an enlarged kidney with areas of necrosis and mottled areas of gas collection. This is suggestive of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

This condition is common in diabetics and refers to a severe form of pyelonephritis with characteristic gas formation within or around the kidneys. If not treated early, it may lead to fulminant sepsis and is associated with high mortality.

CT scan is the best modality for the diagnosis of emphysematous pyelonephritis. The following diagnostic features are seen:

  • Enlarged, destructed renal parenchyma
  • Small bubbly or linear streaks of gas
  • Fluid collections, with gas-fluid levels
  • Focal necrotic areas with or without abscess

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency with a painless mass in his abdomen. Examination revealed a large, mobile abdomen mass that does not cross the midline .  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a large abdominal mass in a young child without pain is strongly suggestive of Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma).

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma): It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (peaks 2-5 years of age).

Other options

  • Renal cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor of adults.
  • Angiomyolipoma may rarely be seen in children.
  • Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood arising from adrenal medulla; however, it presents as a painful, fixed abdominal mass, crossing the midline.

 Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor :

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome

WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p

Genetic basis- 
Two-hit hypothesis

Wilms tumor

Aniridia

Genital anomalies

mental Retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome

Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein

 

Genetic basis- 
Two-hit hypothesis

Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo-hermaphroditism)

Early-onset nephropathy

Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome

IGF-2 overexpression on WT2 region

Genetic basis- 
Genomic imprinting

Organomegaly

Macroglossia

Hemihypertrophy

Omphalocele

Adrenal cytomegaly

Hepatoblastoma, Pancreato-blastoma, Adrenocortical tumors, and Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: Which among the following is the key feature of depression?

choices.text: Loss of interest in pleasurable activties

questions.solution:
The key feature of depression among the given is loss of interest in pleasurable activities.

The Diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder are as follows:

A. Five or more of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period. At least one of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure.

  • Depressed mood most of the day
  • Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia)
  • Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite
  • Insomnia or hypersomnia
  • Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  • Fatigue or loss of energy
  • Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
  • Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
  • Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

B. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupa­tional, or other important areas of functioning.

C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical condition.

D. The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by schizoaf­fective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

questions.text: Which diagnostic technique is the best to assess renal perfusion?
questions.solution:
The best diagnostic technique to assess renal perfusion is the MAG-3 (Mercaptoacetyltriglycine) or DTPA (Diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid) scan.

These are nuclear medicine imaging tests that help evaluate the functional and perfusion aspects of the kidneys. These scans involve injecting a radiopharmaceutical into the bloodstream, which is then filtered by the kidneys. The scan tracks the movement of the radiopharmaceutical through the kidneys, allowing the medical professional to assess renal blood flow, perfusion, and overall kidney function.

Other Options:

Option B- DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan is used to assess renal cortical morphology and function. It is commonly used to evaluate scarring or infection in the kidneys.

Option C- RGU is a radiographic technique used to visualize the urethra and bladder. It is primarily used to diagnose urethral obstructions and other structural abnormalities of the urinary tract. 

Option D- CT urography is used to visualize the urinary tract, including the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. It provides detailed anatomical information but does not focus specifically on assessing renal perfusion.

questions.text: A male patient presented for the evaluation of infertility. He has been having recurrent hospitalizations for infections, since 2 years of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Male infertility and recurrent lung infections are typical findings in Kartagener syndrome/ ciliary dyskinesia.

Kartagener’s syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad of:

  • Situs inversus
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.

As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen, its absence will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality.

Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function). 

Other options:

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where there is an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria which subsequently impairs various nutrient absorption. Clinically, it presents as a malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss.

Cystic Fibrosis: is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. It can present as:

  • Sinusitis and nasal polyps
  • Respiratory - copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions with abnormal mucociliary clearance obstructing small and medium-sized airways leading to respiratory compromise. The disease can be further complicated by bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • Reproductive - males have infertility due to the congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in obstructive azoospermia. Females have infertility due to abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions.

The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:
Presence of

  • clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
  • Positive newborn screening or
  • A sibling with cystic fibrosis

Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by:

  • Two positive sweat chloride test results were obtained on separate days or
    Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
  • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a chronic respiratory disease characterized by the presence of airflow obstruction that is partially reversible. Patients with COPD present with cough, sputum production, and dyspnea on exertion.

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented with diarrhea occurring approximately 20 minutes after meals. She underwent a Billroth I gastrectomy operation.  What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe proton pump inhibitors in combination with amoxicillin.
Consider reversing the surgical procedure from Billroth II to Billroth I
Advise the patient to consume small, frequent meals and increase protein content in their diet.

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has dumping syndrome, and the initial management for this patient is to recommend small frequent meals and increased protein content in the diet to manage symptoms and slow down gastric emptying.

Dumping syndrome is a common complication after gastrectomy, particularly after procedures like Billroth I, where the stomach's capacity is reduced. It occurs due to the rapid emptying of the stomach contents into the small intestine, leading to symptoms like diarrhea, nausea, sweating, and palpitations, typically occurring shortly after meals.

The initial management of dumping syndrome involves dietary modifications. Recommending small, frequent meals can help slow down the rate at which food is emptied from the stomach and prevent the sudden surge in glucose absorption that triggers the symptoms. Increasing the protein content of meals can also help stabilize blood sugar levels and reduce the severity of symptoms.

Other Options:

Option A: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and amoxicillin are not the primary treatments for dumping syndrome. PPIs are used to reduce stomach acid production, while amoxicillin is an antibiotic. Neither directly addresses the underlying issue of rapid gastric emptying and glucose absorption seen in dumping syndrome.

Option B: Insulin and glucose are not typically used as initial management for dumping syndrome. Dumping syndrome involves rapid glucose absorption, and managing it through dietary adjustments is usually the first step.

Option C: Reversing the surgical procedure to Billroth 1 or Roux-en-Y is a more drastic option that might be considered if dietary modifications do not effectively manage the symptoms of dumping syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following should be used for pre-operative management in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Alpha-blockers like phenoxybenzamine are given pre-operatively to manage hypertension in pheochromocytoma. Beta-blockers such as propranolol are given only after adequate alpha blockade is achieved.

The drug of choice to control blood pressure prior to surgery is oral phenoxybenzamine at 0.5–4 mg/kg of body weight. It is a non-specific α-blocker and is preferred due to its long action (3-4 days).

Pheochromocytoma:

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.

It can be sporadical or hereditary. Hereditary pheochromocytoma occurs in association with syndromes such as MEN 2 (Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2), familial paraganglioma syndrome, Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) syndrome, and neurofibromatosis (NF) type 1.

Clinical features:

It most commonly presents as a classic triad of intermittent headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating along with hypertension. The patient can also present with anxiety, panic attacks, nausea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and weakness.

Symptoms may be precipitated by surgery, pregnancy, position changes, exercise, and medications such as metoclopramide and tricyclic antidepressants.

Investigations:

  1. Biochemical screening test - measurement of urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines. 
  2. MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor. It is preferred over a CT scan as the contrast used in CT scans can precipitate paroxysms.
  3. Other imaging modalities like MIBG scintigraphy, DOPA- or FDG- PET scan are used in identifying the primary tumor as well as the extra-adrenal tumors and metastases.

Treatment:

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma.

Preoperatively, hypertension is managed initially with alpha-blockers followed by beta-blockers.

Postoperatively, lifelong yearly follow-up should be done.

questions.text: A patient presented after a road traffic accident (RTA) with a head injury. CT head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and the CT image are suggestive of a depressed skull fracture of the left frontal bone.

A depressed skull fracture occurs when a portion of the skull is pushed inward due to trauma, creating a depression in the bone. This type of fracture can occur as a result of a direct impact to the head, such as in a road traffic accident.

The management of depressed skull fractures:

  • The first step is to order a CT scan to know the degree of depression and to exclude the presence of an intracranial hematoma or contusion.
  • The depressed fracture is elevated and managed as an open fracture (surgery) if:
    • The degree of depression is greater than the thickness of the adjacent skull
    • The wound is are open and grossly contaminated
    • There are focal neurological deficits
  • Less severe depressed fractures are managed by the closure of the overlying scalp laceration, if present.

Other options:

Option A: Concussion refers to a temporary disturbance in brain function following head trauma and typically does not show up on CT scans.

Option B: Epidural hematoma often appears as a lens-shaped collection of blood on CT scans.

Option D: Subarachnoid hemorrhage may appear as diffuse or localized blood on imaging.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding per vagina and slight abdominal pain. A diagnosis of unruptured ectopic pregnancy was made. Baseline beta HCG was measured and medical management with 50mg/m2 of methotrexate was started (Day 1). The serum beta HCG level measured on Day 2 was more than the baseline beta HCG level. What is the appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Measure beta HCG levels on day 4 and 7

questions.solution:
Following the administration of methotrexate mean beta hCG levels may rise during the first 4 days followed by a gradual decline. Hence the next best step, in this case, is to measure beta HCG levels on day 4 and day 7.

MTX Protocol Multi-dose regimen Single-dose regimen
Dose 

1 mg/kg
(+ 0.1 mg/kg Leucovorin)

50 mg/m2
(Body surface area)
Regimen

Methotrexate - days 1, 3, 5, 7 

Leucovorin - days 2, 4, 6, 8

 Day 1
hCG measurement Days 1(baseline), 3, 5, 7 Days 1(baseline), 4, 7
Treatment success hCG declines >15% from the previous value hCG declines >15% between Day 4 and 7
When to administer an additional dose (Option B)

If serum β-hCG level declines <15%, give additional dose; repeat serum β-hCG in 48 hours and compare with the previous value; a maximum of 4 doses

  
  • If serum β-hCG level does not decline by 15% from day 4 to day 7
  • Less than 15% decline during weekly surveillance
 

If the decline is ≥15%, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L. A repeat dose is required if the decline is less than 15% between days 4 and 7 - about 20% women would need a repeat dose.

 Medical management is preferred in the following cases:

  • Low initial serum beta-hCG level (Less than 3,000 IU/L)
  • Small ectopic pregnancy size (Less than 4 cm)
  • Absent fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable

Other options

Option A:

Surgical management with salpingectomy or salpingostomy is done when:

  • Criteria for medical management are not met
  • Persistent fetal cardiac activity
  • Cases where beta hCG levels are not decreasing despite medical therapy.

Option C:

The next best step in the management in this case is to measure beta hCG levels. An alternative regimen with KCL is not recommended in this case.

questions.text: A primigravida woman gives birth to a baby with the following defect. Identify the anomaly.
questions.solution:
The above image showing anencephaly and a contiguous bony defect of the spine, is suggestive of craniorachischisis. It occurs due to failure of complete closure of the neural tube.

Rachischisis is the most severe type of neural tube defect, where the entire neural tube fails to close. Rachischisis can occur in the spinal cord or brain regions of the neural tube. The exposed neural tissues often become necrotic. 

The image given below shows craniorachischisis.

Spina bifida is a general term used for neural tube defects affecting the spinal region and associated with splitting of the vertebral arches. It is characterized by gaps in the vertebral arches and may or may not involve the underlying neural tissue.

The illustration shown below shows spina bifida.

The 3 main types of spina bifida:

  • Spina bifida occulta - This is the mildest form of spina bifida. The defect in the vertebral arches is covered by the skin. The splits in the vertebrae are so small that the spinal cord does not protrude. The skin at the site of the lesion may be normal, or it may have some hair growing from it.
  • Meningocele - The defect in the vertebra allows the meninges to protrude through the defect.
  • Myelomeningocele (meningomyelocele) - Defect in the vertebral column allows the spinal cord with the meningeal coverings to protrude. 

The image given below shows the different types of spina bifida.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with a smooth transition and is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain and on examination, the right adnexal mass was palpable, non-tender. On USG examination she has a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary. Which is the next step?

choices.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualise the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a simple post-menopausal cyst of size 3x3 cm and the next step is to evaluate CA-125 levels and calculate RMI (risk of malignancy index) before proceeding with regular follow-up. 

Initial steps in management include the following:

  • Estimate CA–125 levels
  • USG
  • Calculating the Risk of Malignancy index
    • RMI = U x  M  x  Ca-125
    • U – Ultrasound score
    • M – Menopausal status
    • Ca 125 – Serum levels

Other options: 

Option B: CT scan is not recommended in the initial evaluation.

Option C: Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size >5 cm or RMI >200.

questions.text: McCall culdoplasty is done in which of the following?
questions.solution:
McCall's culdoplasty is used in enterocele repair.

An enterocele is herniation of the pouch of Douglas and small bowel loops into the rectovaginal septum. Enteroceles are most commonly associated with uterine prolapse. Patients present with the following clinical features:

  • Fecal incontinence
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Constipation/diarrhea
  • Mass descending PV
  • Pelvic pain or pelvic discomfort
  • A bulge in the posterior vaginal wall:
    • Upper 1/3rd - enterocele
    • Lower 2/3rd - rectocele
  • Peristalsis may be observed in the bulge 

Enterocele repair is done via the following methods:

  • Vaginal approach - it is usually preferred over an abdominal approach. In McCall's culdoplasty, the uterosacral ligaments are used to suspend the vaginal vault. The posterior peritoneum and uterosacral ligaments are approximated. 
  • Abdominal approach - it is preferred in cases where there is associated fecal incontinence. It includes:
    • Moschcowitz repair - the pouch of Douglas is obliterated by several purse-string sutures.
    • Halban's procedure - the peritoneal sac is obliterated using vertical sutures. This can also be done transvaginally.

questions.text: Identify the given logo below?
questions.solution:
The given logo is of the Bureau of Indian Standards.

BIS is the National Standard Body of India established under the BIS Act 2016 for the harmonious development of the activities of standardization, marking and quality certification of goods.

BIS has been providing traceability and tangibility benefits to the national economy in a number of ways – providing safe reliable quality goods; minimizing health hazards to consumers; promoting export and import substitutes; controlling over proliferation of varieties etc. through standardization, certification and testing.

Other options:

Option C: The Food Corporation of India implements the objectives of the National Food Policy:

  • Effective price support operations for safeguarding the interests of poor farmers
  • Distribution of foodgrains throughout the country for Public Distribution System (PDS)
  • Maintaining a satisfactory level of operational and buffer stocks of foodgrains to ensure National Food Security
  • Regulate market price to provide foodgrains to consumers at a reliable price

 

Option A: AGMARK is a certification mark employed on agricultural products in India, assuring that they conform to a set of standards approved by the Directorate of Marketing and Inspection, an agency of the Government of India.

Option D: Goods and Services Tax (GST) is an indirect tax (or consumption tax) used in India on the supply of goods and services. It is a comprehensive, multistage, destination-based tax.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the OPD with the following findings. On examination, there is high-riding scapula with medial rotation on the left. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an upward elevation of the left scapula relative to the thoracic cage. This is characteristically seen in Sprengel deformity.

Sprengel deformity is a congenital upward elevation of the scapula. It is due to the failure of the scapula to descend completely in embryonic life.

The affected scapula is smaller, shaped differently, abnormally high, and somewhat prominent. Shoulder movements are usually painless. Abduction and elevation of shoulders may be limited due to fixation of the scapula.

The Cavendish classification is used to grade the severity of Sprengel deformity. 

If the deformity is mild, no treatment is required. In severe deformity, surgery may be indicated. These procedures include:

  • Green procedure
  • Woodward procedure
  • Mears procedure

questions.text: A female patient presents with ambiguous genitalia and rapid virilization. She also complains of excessive facial hair growth, voice deepening, and an enlarged clitoris over the past few months. CT scan is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presented clinical scenario, along with the CT scan findings of bilaterally enlarged adrenal glands with nodules in the adrenal cortex, suggests a likely diagnosis of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH).

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a disorder of cortisol synthesis. It has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. Cortisol deficiency increases the secretion of the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), causing adrenal hyperplasia with the overproduction of intermediate metabolites. This child has clitoromegaly due to increased androgen synthesis. The enzyme 21-hydroxylase helps in the downstream synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. A deficiency of aldosterone causes salt wasting that presents as low blood pressure.

The presentation depends on the enzyme that is deficient, which could result in mineralocorticoid deficiency or excess, incomplete virilization or precocious puberty in affected males, and virilization or sexual infantilism in affected females.

Given below is the pathway and enzymes involved in adrenal steroid synthesis:

Other options:

Adrenocortical carcinoma might appear as a large, irregular mass within the adrenal gland. The mass could have areas of necrosis or hemorrhage, contributing to its irregular appearance. 

A pheochromocytoma typically presents as a well-defined, solid mass within the adrenal gland. It might be associated with areas of hemorrhage, leading to a heterogeneous appearance. 

The adrenal glands may appear normal in size or slightly enlarged on a CT scan in case of primary hyperaldosteronism. There might not be distinct masses or nodules in the adrenal glands.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-Hydroxylase 17-Hydroxylase 11β-Hydroxylase 3β-HSD

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone;

↑ in testosterone

 Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones; ↑ in aldosterone Deficiency of cortisol; ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone and testosterone; ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency, Aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Which test is being performed to detect fixed flexion deformity at hip?
questions.solution:
Thomas test is used to detect fixed flexion deformity of the hip. 

Flexion deformity is seen in the initial stages of the disease. The patient keeps the hip in flexion as this is the position of ease and maximum joint capacity. Soft tissue contractures convert this into a fixed flexion deformity, making locomotion impossible.

In an effort to bring the limb on the ground and to make locomotion possible, the lumbar spine undergoes exaggerated lordosis and thus conceals the fixed flexion deformity. This is revealed by the Thomas test. The easy passage of the examiner's hand between the bed and the back of the patient is considered as a positive test as normally this is not possible.

Other options: 

  • Trendelenburg test is used to assess the weakness or paralysis of gluteus medius muscle. 
  • Telescopy test: To asses the stability of the hip joint. Positive telescopy test indicates hip dislocations or fracture neck of femur.
  • Ober's test is used in physical examination to identify the tightness of the iliotibial band.

questions.text: A young male patient developed abdominal pain for which he was being evaluated. CT and IVU findings are given below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given images show a horseshoe kidney. It is prone to obstruction, reflux, and stone formation (the likely cause of pain in this case)

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys with male preponderance

Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney. The lower border of the kidneys usually lies in front of the L3 vertebra due to the arrest of ascent.

The common associations of horseshoe kidney are:

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux
  • Wilms Tumor
  • Multicystic Dysplastic Kidney
  • Turner’s Syndrome

IVU findings of a Horseshoe kidney:

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

questions.text: Which of the following undergoes Hofmann elimination?
questions.solution:
Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination, which is spontaneous non-enzymatic degradation.

Rocuronium, and vecuronium are dependent on the liver for excretion. Pancuronium excretion is primarily renal. A small percentage of the drug is excreted through bile (hepatic elimination).

questions.text: A statistician is working with a gynecologist on a study about “Awareness regarding Pap smear.” They administer a questionnaire with 50 questions to 200 women, and each correct response gets 1 point. They find that the data are positively skewed. Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively, of the same?
questions.solution:
In a positively skewed data set, mean>median>mode. Hence, here, the mean, median, and mode must be 25, 23, and 20 respectively. None of the other options is consistent with mean > median > mode.

The observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency is known as the mode. If there are two values that occur with the same greatest frequency, the distribution is bimodal. If there are more than two such values, the distribution becomes multimodal. 

When all the values are listed in order, the value that divides the distribution in half is known as the median. When there are an even number of values, the median is obtained by calculating the mean of the two middle scores.

The mean (average) is obtained by summing up all the values and dividing the obtained sum by the total number of values in the distribution.

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve.

In the image, the tail is located on the positive side of the graph (right side) and so it is a positive or right-skewed distribution. A positively skewed data set contains a large number of low scores but a small number of very high scores. It is vice versa in negatively skewed distributions.

In a negatively skewed distribution, mean<median<mode. This is shown in option A.

In a normal distribution, mean=median=mode, as shown in option C.

questions.text: Which electrolyte abnormality has to be considered in a patient with the following ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG classically depicts polymorphic ventricular tachycardia—torsades de pointes. Torsade rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.

Torsades de pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia meaning “twisting of the points,” characterized by twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance.

There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization.

The other cause of torsades de pointes include:

  • Class 1 and Class 3 Anti-Arrhythmic drugs
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction

Management:

  • Discontinue the offending drug
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, pH, and hypoxia
  • Magnesium sulfate infusion 
  • Increase the heart rate - electrical pacing, isoproterenol infusion, or intravenous atropine 

Note: Although hypocalcemia is associated with prolongation of QT interval, there are only rare reports of torsades de pointes associated with hypocalcemia. So, among the above options, the best answer would be hypokalemia.

questions.text: A female undergoes a methylene blue 3 swab test and the middle swab is stained with blue. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with methylene blue swab test showing staining of middle swab is suggestive of vesicovaginal fistula.

Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract. It can be classified as simple or complicated. Their features are given in the table below. 

Simple VVF Complicated VVF
Size ≤ 3 cm Size > 3 cm
Located near the cuff or supra-trigonal Located away from the cuff / there is the involvement of trigone 
No prior malignancy Pelvic malignancy present
No prior radiation Prior radiation therapy
The vaginal length remains normal Vaginal length shortened
 
Vesicovaginal fistulae occur mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine. The presence of urine in the undergarments is uncomfortable and leads to pruritus and excoriation of the genital area. 

Investigations to be performed include

  • Urine culture and treatment of infection if required
  • Ultrasound of the kidney, ureter, and bladder
  • Intravenous pyelography
  • Methylene blue - 3 swab test if the fistula is small. Here, methylene blue is injected into the bladder via the catheter, and three sterile swabs are placed into the vaginal cavity.  
    • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
    • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
    • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula
  • Cystourethroscopy helps in fistula localization, determination of its proximity to the ureteral orifices, inspection for multiple fistula sites, etc.

Vesicovaginal fistula is treated surgically. It can be attempted after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside and clear the infection. After this, the Latzko procedure can be performed. Here, the vaginal epithelium around the fistula is removed and the edges are approximated. The Chassar Moir technique can also be attempted. Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured into two layers taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines.

questions.text: A young primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation was admitted since her BP was 150/90 mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup.  On examination, she has pedal edema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario suggests a likely diagnosis of pre-eclampsia.

Pre-eclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery. It is characterized by blood pressure of >140/90 mmHg on two occasions 4 hours apart with proteinuria or signs of end-organ damage.

Criteria to diagnose pre-eclampsia:

  • Proteinuria of ≥ 300 mg (0.3 g) in 24 hours or urine protein:creatinine ratio of ≥0.3
  • Platelet count of <1 lakh/cu.mm
  • Serum creatinine level of >1.1 mg/dL
  • Serum transaminase levels twice the normal concentration
  • Headache, visual disturbances, or epigastric pain
  • Pulmonary edema

Clinical types of pre-eclampsia:

  • Nonsevere pre-eclampsia: Blood pressure >140/90 mmHg but <160/110 mmHg without significant proteinuria
  • Severe pre-eclampsia: Persistent increase of systolic blood pressure above 160 mmHg or diastolic above 110 mmHg with any of the following, proteinuria, oliguria (<400 mL in 24 hours), platelet count <1 lakh/cu.mm, serum creatinine level of >1.1 mg/dL, persistent severe epigastric pain, marked elevation of liver enzyme levels, cerebral (convulsions) or visual disturbances, intrauterine growth restriction of the fetus, and pulmonary edema.

Complications of pre-eclampsia:

  • Eclampsia
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • Cerebral hemorrhage
  • Preterm labor
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Shock
  • Sepsis

questions.text: As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, when can an MTP be performed on grounds of contraceptive failure?
questions.solution:
As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act of 2021, the upper limit for termination of pregnancy on grounds of contraceptive failure is 20 weeks. 

The MTP Act of 2021 specifies special circumstances for termination of pregnancy beyond 20 weeks till 24 weeks of gestation. These include:

  • Survivor of sexual assault, rape or incest.
  • Minors
  • Mentally ill women including mental retardation
  • Change of marital status during the ongoing pregnancy (widowhood and divorce)
  • Women with physical disabilities (Major disability criteria - Rights of persons with disabilities act - 2016)
  • Women with pregnancy in humanitarian settings or disaster or emergency situations as declared by the government.
  • Fetal malformations that have a substantial risk of being incompatible with life or if the child is born, may suffer from serious physical or mental abnormalities to be seriously handicapped. (Option A)

Termination of pregnancy can be done only up to 20 weeks based on grounds of contraception failure.

  • Until 20 weeks of gestation - Opinion of one doctor  
  • 20-24 weeks of gestation - Opinion of two doctors
  • The name and particulars of the woman whose pregnancy has been terminated cannot be disclosed. It can only be revealed to a person in force authorised by law. The ground for failure of contraception is extended to women and their partners.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A female patient presents with a hard and irregular lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast.  The histopathological slide of the mass sample is given below. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Single line of cells are seen lining the normal duct (bottom right of the image) which is the characteristic Indian file/ Single file appearance.

The histopathological image shows discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, signet-ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, and the Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Tubule formation is absent in this subtype.

Lobular Carcinoma:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Multicentric and presents as hard irregular masses
  • It can have a diffuse infiltrative pattern with minimal desmoplasia
  • It is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B: Papillary carcinoma consists of true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue, lined by the tumor cells.

 

Option C: Medullary carcinoma of the breast shows sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates and pushing border.

 

Option D: Colloidal carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intra and extracellular mucin deposition. Extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei arranged in clusters floating in pools/lakes of mucin on histopathological examination. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the peripherally to form signet ring appearance.

questions.text: Identify the plant shown below:
questions.solution:
The plant shown above is the Cerbera Thevetia.

Thevetin is a cardiac poison derived from the plant Cerbera Thevetia (yellow oleander). All parts of the plant are poisonous. Symptoms of intoxication are characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, mydriasis, and loss of muscular power. Cardiovascular signs include a weak and irregular pulse rate with hypotension. Possible complications are heart block and cardiorespiratory failure. 

Other options:

Digoxin is a cardiac poison derived from the roots, leaves, and seeds of the plant Digitalis Purpurea (shown below). 

Aconite is a cardiac poison derived mainly from the root and root tubers of the plant Aconite Napellus (shown below).

Nicotine is a plant alkaloid derived from the Nicotiana Tabacum plant shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of pseudohallucination?
questions.solution:
Pseudohallucination is a disorder of perception like hallucinations. They are sensory deceptions without any actual stimulus. These perceptions are often vivid and not under voluntary control. They are triggered by various events

  • Intense emotional triggers
  • Suggestions from immediate surroundings
  • Psychiatric disorders like schizrophrenia 
  • Diseases of sense organs
  • Sensory deprivation
  • Diseases of central nervous system

The prime difference of pseudohallucinations lies in the fact that they occur in the inner subjective space, i.e., they are experienced in the mind of the subject. Hallucinations on the other hand are perceived in the objective space, ie the surroundings of the subject and can be heard or seen form the surroundings by the subject. Pseudohallucinations don't point towards a psychological pathology as it can occur in psychologically sound individuals as well.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room after a road traffic accident in an unconscious state. He has a head injury. On examination, he has bradycardia and hypertension. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was 6. What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation of level of consciousness, bradycardia, and high blood pressure after a head injury, the next appropriate step is to intubate and provide ventilation to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation while managing potential increased intracranial pressure.

Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea).

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised. This leads to local hypoxia and hypercapnia which in turn increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors located on the ventrolateral medullary surface. This activation causes a rise in blood pressure which then restores the blood flow to the medulla.

However, the arterial baroreceptors sense this increase in the systemic blood pressure and cause a reflex decrease in the heart rate. 

Other Options:

Option A: CT head is not the immediate priority in a patient with compromised consciousness and potentially raised ICP. Ensuring proper ventilation and oxygenation takes precedence.

Option C: The patient's symptoms are likely related to the head injury, and thrombolysis is not the appropriate intervention at this time.

Option D: Administering IV fluids might be important in some situations, such as maintaining blood pressure in a hypotensive patient. However, it does not directly address the patient's altered consciousness and potentially raised ICP.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

Half-hourly for 2 hours,
Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
Then 2-hourly thereafter.
Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <13 at any point
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours

  • Age >65 years
  • Coagulopathy (e.g., aspirin, warfarin, or rivaroxaban use)
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: A patient received a tubal block and is scheduled for laparoscopy. Identify the instrument used in this procedure.
questions.solution:
Veress needle is used to produce pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery.

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger.
Because the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or penetrating towel clip to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures. (As shown below)

Other options:

Option A: The image given below is that of a Hasson trocar which is used in the open method of creating pneumoperitoneum.To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar, shown below, is inserted and anchored, and pneumoperitoneum is created. This is the Hasson or modified Hasson approach. This avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture. 

Option C: Leech Wilkinson's Cannula is dipicted below.It can be identified by the spiral cone at the tip and is used for hysterosalpingography.Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radiopaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

Option D: Whitacre Needle dipicted below and it is a Dura Splitting Needle. Dura-splitting needles include Sprotte, Whitacre, and Greene. They have a pencil-point, rounded and conical tip which splits the layers of dura. Thus, the loss of CSF is reduced and PDPH is lesser with these needles

questions.text: A 20-year-old nulligravida presented with right flank pain. MRI evaluation revealed a solid, enhancing  5×13×7 cm right ovarian mass. Salpingo-oophorectomy was successfully done and microscopic examination of the tumor cells showed a close resemblance to primordial germ cells. It was also noticed that the tumor appeared histologically identical to a testicular seminoma. Which of the following is not secreted by this tumor?
questions.solution:
An ovarian tumor in a young woman which consists of primordial germ cells and is histologically similar to seminoma suggests a diagnosis of an ovarian dysgerminoma. It does not secrete sex hormones.

Dysgerminoma usually arises in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumour diagnosed during pregnancy. They are primitive neoplasms that do not have the potential for further differentiation. They are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%).

The tumor is neutral and does not secrete either male or female sex hormones. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and β-hCG. Serum LDH and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.

Microscopically, there is a monotonous proliferation of large, rounded, polyhedral clear cells that are rich in cytoplasmic glycogen and contain uniform central nuclei with one or a few prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells are histologically identical to the seminoma of the testis. The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma. 

Treatment involves fertility-sparing surgery with unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

The image below shows the histopathology of a dygerminoma, characterized by uniform cells resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes. 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller duval bodies

Dysgerminoma

(Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)
