  • P: PLAP
  • L: LDH

questions.text: You are performing a cardiotocograph on a woman in labor, and your findings are shown below. What could be the possible cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
The given cardiotocograph shows decelerations that are variable with respect to the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions. This is indicative of variable decelerations, and the likely cause among the given options is umbilical cord compression

Baseline variability is observed in many conditions such as:

1. Acceleration: Transient increase in fetal heart rate (FHR) by 15 bpm or more, lasting for at least 15 seconds. It denotes intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular activity and, therefore, a healthy fetus.

2. Deceleration: Transient decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more and lasting ≥15 seconds. Three basic types of deceleration are early, late, and variable:

  • Early deceleration/ Type I Dips: Slowing of FHR and in most cases, the phases of the deceleration (onset, nadir, and recovery) coincide with those of the uterine contraction (beginning, peak, and ending). It is due to head compression (vagal nerve activation).

 

  • Late deceleration/ Type II Dips: that begins after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak and end of the uterine contraction respectively. It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia (50%). Causes of late deceleration: (i) Placental pathology (postmaturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption); (ii) Excessive uterine contractions; (iii) Injudicious use of oxytocin; (iv) Regional anaesthesia (spinal or epidural)

 

  • Variable deceleration: The most common type of deceleration. Here the decelerations are variable, with varying parameters of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing with respect to uterine contractions. They indicate cord compression and may disappear when the patient's position is altered. Accelerations often precede and follow this type of deceleration.

 

3. Prolonged deceleration is the abrupt decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline, and it lasts for >3 min but <10 min. If it lasts for >10 min, it is a baseline change.

4. Lag period: It is the time taken for the FHR to reach the nadir (the lowest point of the FHR dip) from the apex of the preceding uterine contraction. In deceleration, the lag period is >30 seconds.

5. Sinusoidal pattern: It resembles a sine wave. It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting >20 min. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anaemia and fetomaternal haemorrhage. It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother. Such FHR patterns are called pseudo-sinusoidal as the fetus is well-oxygenated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man had severe hypothyroidism.  His arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows very low pO2 and high pCO2 levels.  Which of the following types of respiratory failure is likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of severe hypothyroidism with hypoxemia and hypercapnia is suggestive of type 2 respiratory failure. 

Type II respiratory failure occurs as a consequence of alveolar hypoventilation and results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. The mechanism of type II respiratory failure in severe hypothyroidism can be due to poor response of the central nervous system to hypoxia and hypercapnia, aw well as reduced strength of the respiratory muscles.

Other causes for diminished CNS drive to breathe:

  • Drug overdose
  • Brainstem injury
  • Sleep-disordered breathing 

Reduced strength for respiration can be due to

  • Impaired neuromuscular transmission (e.g., myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis)
  • Respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., myopathy, electrolyte derangements, fatigue, )

The overall load on the respiratory system that can facilitate type 2 respiratory failure can be classified as follows:

  • Resistive loads as in bronchospasm
  • Loads due to reduced lung compliance as in alveolar edema, atelectasis, intrinsic positive end-expiratory pressure
  • Loads due to reduced chest wall compliance as in pneumothorax, pleural effusion, abdominal distention
  • Loads due to increased minute ventilation requirements as in pulmonary embolus with increased dead-space fraction, sepsis

Treatment:

Reversing the underlying causes of ventilatory failure remains the mainstay treatment for type 2 respiratory failure. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation with a tight-fitting facial or nasal mask and avoidance of endotracheal intubation often stabilizes patients with type 2 respiratory failure. This approach is beneficial in treating patients with exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Related Pearl: Types of respiratory failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology. Sepsis, gastric aspiration, pneumonia, near-drowning, multiple blood transfusions and pancreatitis.
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

 Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. Drug overdose, brainstem injury, sleep-disordered breathing, severe hypothyroidism, myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barre syndrome and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she presented with seizures, aphasia, and hemiparesis. Which of the following investigations is useful to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cortical vein thrombosis. This condition can be diagnosed using MR venography.

Cortical vein thrombosis :    

Risk factors:

  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Prothrombotic conditions

Clinical presentation is highly variable. Headache is the most common symptom. Motor or sensory deficits may be seen. Seizures along with focal deficits in the absence of raised intracranial pressure are suggestive of cortical venous thrombosis. Brain MRI with MR venography is a sensitive investigation to diagnose this condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with joint pain which increases in the early morning when he wakes up and decreases with activity. Examination reveals the following picture (given below) along with inflammation of the wrist. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the above image with nail pitting and yellowing of the nails and inflammation of the DIP joints, point to a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. 

Psoriasis is a papulosquamous disease with joint and nail manifestations apart from the skin. It has silvery scales.

The joint manifestations in psoriasis are referred to as psoriatic arthritis. It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy and hence it is associated with HLA-B27. It is seen in 5-30% of patients with cutaneous manifestations. Nail involvement increases the risk of concomitant joint involvement.

Other features:

  • Psoriatic nail changes like yellowing and hypertrophy 
  • Inflammation of the toes- dactylitis
  • Shortening of toes- telescoping (because of osteolysis)
  • Severe deformity- suggestive of arthritis mutilans
  • Associated heel pain- suggestive of enthesitis (pain at the sites of ligament/tendon attachment)

The x-ray shows 'pencil in cup' deformity due to tapering of phalanges with cupping of proximal parts. Also all the bones of a single digit maybe involved refered to as ray deformity.

The drug of choice for different types of psoriasis is shown in the pearl below.

The most likely diagnosis for this patient's joint pain, which worsens in the early morning and improves with activity, along with the given picture showing nail changes and inflammation of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, is Psoriatic Arthritis.

Psoriatic arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. It is categorized under the seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is often linked to the presence of HLA-B27. It is seen in 5-30% of patients with cutaneous manifestations. Nail involvement increases the risk of concomitant joint involvement. 

Some key features associated with psoriatic arthritis:

  • Psoriatic nail changes like yellowing and hypertrophy 
  • Inflammation of the toes - dactylitis (sausage appearance).
  • Shortening of toes - telescoping (because of osteolysis)
  • Severe deformity - suggestive of arthritis mutilans
  • Associated heel pain - suggestive of enthesitis (pain at the sites of ligament/tendon attachment)
  • Radiographic findings, including the "pencil-in-cup" deformity, which results from the tapering of phalanges and cupping of proximal parts.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with complaints of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. A USG scan was done and is shown below. Which of the following hormonal levels need to be checked in this patient?

hCG - Human Chorionic Gonadotropin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy and beta hCG levels need to be measured.

Molar pregnancy may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG.  

Suction and evacuation is the treatment of choice. The patient is followed up every week till the hCG levels normalize, after which follow-up is done monthly for 6 months.

Post-evacuation recommendations:

  • Anti-D immune globulin if Rh D-negative
  • Initiate effective contraception (IUD contraindicated)
  • Review pathology report
  • Serum hCG levels: within 48 h of evacuation, weekly until undetectable, then monthly for 6 months.

Pregnancy is allowed after 6 months following a negative hCG titer. However, it is advised to avoid pregnancy for 1 year, preferably 2 years, as a fresh pregnancy will interfere with the hCG titers.

questions.text: Management of an appendicular mass in appendicitis is _______
questions.solution:
Ochsner–Sherren regimen is indicated for patients with appendicular mass in whom conditions are stable.

The patient's temperature and pulse rate are recorded 4-hourly and adequate fluid balance is maintained. CECT abdomen is done and antibiotic therapy is started. Abscess if present is drained. Improvement is usually seen within 24–48 hours.

Ochsner–Sherren regimen:

Principle :

  • The inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous.
  • It may be impossible to find the appendix and, occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.
  • Antibiotic therapy should be given after performing CECT abdomen
  • Abscess if present can be drained radiologically.

Outcome :

  • Improvement in 24–48 h
  • 90% cases resolve
  • Failure should raise suspicion of Crohn’s disease and carcinoma. 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of Appendicular mass:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increasing size of the mass
 

Other options:

  • Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis.
  • If the patient's condition deteriorates or if there is evidence of peritonitis, laparotomy is performed.
  • Incision and drainage are not done in appendicitis.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed some locally produced spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of methanol toxicity. Ethanol and fomepizole is used for the treatment of this condition.

Methanol poisoning is caused due to ingestion of illicit liquor which contains ethanol adulterated with methanol. Methanol is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid by alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenases, respectively. The metabolites of methanol are responsible for the toxic effects.

Clinically, patients present with headache, vomiting, abdomen pain, uneasiness, confusion, delirium, and coma. Formic acid specifically damages the retina and optic nerve and results in blurring of vision and blindness.

Elevated levels of formic acid and other organic acids result in metabolic acidosis in arterial blood gas analysis(ABG).

Treatment of methanol poisoning includes gastric lavage with sodium bicarbonate if the patient is brought within 2 hours of ingesting methanol to combat acidosis. Ethanol infusion since ethanol is preferentially metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase over methanol and helps by reducing the rate of generation of formaldehyde and formic acid.

Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase and the drug of choice for methanol poisoning. Folate therapy with calcium leucovorin reduces blood formate levels by enhancing its oxidation. Hemodialysis is used in severe cases of methanol toxicity.

Other options: 

Option B: Flumazenil is the inverse agonist of benzodiazepine receptors and is used for the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose.

Option C: Diazepam can be used to manage delirium tremens, or seizures due to alcohol withdrawal.

Option D: Naloxone is a competitive opioid antagonist used for the treatment of opioid overdose.

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibody isotype is involved in the pathogenesis of Acute inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)?
questions.solution:
IgG isotype of autoantibody is involved in the pathogenesis of Acute inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP), which is a type of Guillian Barre syndrome (GBS).

IgM isotype autoantibodies are known to play a role in some types of chronic immune neuropathies.

Antibodies seen in GBS:

Type Antibody
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) Anti GM1
Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN) Anti GD1a
Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN) Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct cause of maternal death?
questions.solution:
Eclampsia is a direct cause of maternal death, whereas the other options given are indirect causes of maternal death.

The ICD(International Classification of Diseases) has recommended dividing maternal deaths into two groups :

  • Direct obstetric deaths are maternal deaths resulting from obstetric complications of the pregnant state like pregnancy, labor and puerperium or from interventions like incorrect treatment or a chain of events resulting from any of the above.
  • Indirect obstetric deaths are maternal deaths resulting from previous existing diseases or diseases that developed during pregnancy and which were not due to direct obstetric causes, but which were aggravated by physiological effects of pregnancy.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are:

  • Severe bleeding
  • Indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases)
  • Direct causes (infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.).

questions.text: Which gas is commonly used in pneumoperitoneum, which involves inflating the abdominal cavity during laparoscopic surgery?
questions.solution:
The correct gas used in pneumoperitoneum is carbon dioxide. Pneumoperitoneum is a technique used in laparoscopic or minimally invasive surgery to create a working space within the abdominal cavity.

CO2 is the preferred gas for this purpose due to several reasons:

  1. Non-Flammable: CO2 is non-flammable, making it safer to use in surgical procedures where electrical equipment is in close proximity.

  2. Minimal Absorption: CO2 is minimally absorbed by the body, which means it can be introduced into the abdominal cavity without causing significant physiological changes.

  3. Rapid Absorption: CO2 is quickly absorbed into the bloodstream and can be eliminated through respiration after the procedure, reducing the risk of post-operative complications.

  4. Low Cost: CO2 is readily available and cost-effective.

Other Options:

  • Oxygen is not used for pneumoperitoneum due to its flammable nature. In the presence of electrical equipment and surgical tools, using oxygen would pose a significant fire hazard.
  • Nitrous oxide is not commonly used for pneumoperitoneum because it is a greenhouse gas and has poor absorption characteristics. It can lead to increased intra-abdominal pressure and potential complications.
  • Nitrogen is not typically used for pneumoperitoneum because it is also a non-absorbable gas. This means it would remain in the body after the surgery, potentially causing discomfort and complications.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presents with extreme pain in the right side of his trunk. On examination, blisters and a woody surface are noted. The image of his trunk is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus). 

Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues and fascia. The source of the infection is either the skin following trauma or a surgical incision. Diabetes mellitus is the most common comorbidity associated with the condition.

Local symptoms and signs are pain, erythema, edema, warmth, crepitus, blisters, bullae, greyish drainage (‘dishwater pus’), necrosis, and gangrene. Systemic features are fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, shock, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure.

Treatment involves appropriate intravenous antibiotics with urgent radical surgical debridement.

Other options:

Option A: Gas gangrene is a form of myonecrosis caused by Clostridium perfringens. Patients who are immunocompromised are at a greater risk. Features are severe local wound pain and crepitus. Large doses of intravenous antibiotics and aggressive debridement of affected tissues are required.

The below image shows bluish-black discoloration and hemorrhagic bullae due to gas gangrene.

Option C: Cellulitis is an infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissues. The point of entry may be a traumatic or surgical wound. Group B streptococci are the major causative organism. There is poor localisation and tissue destruction, gangrene and ulceration may follow, which are caused by the release of proteases. 

Option D: Erysipelas is an infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. The given image shows erysipelas.

questions.text: The screening method for GDM recommended in India is done between:
questions.solution:
Universal screening for GDM is done for all pregnant women. The first testing should be done during the first antenatal contact as early as possible in pregnancy. The second testing should be done during 24-28 weeks of pregnancy if the first test is negative.

The screening method for GDM recommended in India is a 75 gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) irrespective of the last meal timing. A value of ≥140 mg/dL after 2 hours is considered a positive test, indicating GDM.

Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) refers to any degree of glucose intolerance having its onset or first recognition during pregnancy. 

For IADPSG criteria, an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is done in the fasting state using 75 g of glucose, and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is diagnosed if any one of the following cut-offs is met i.e.

  • Fasting: >92 mg/dl 
  • 1 hour: >180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hour: >153 mg/dl

Earlier, a two-step approach was being used to diagnose GDM. In this, the first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). The patients having a positive result of >140mg/dl, are candidates for the OGTT. A 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT), is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. GDM is diagnosed if two or more values are positive.

Diabetes in Pregnancy Societies of India(DIPSI) recommends a 1-step procedure with 75 g oral glucose without regard to the time of the last meal. A venous plasma glucose value at 2 hours >140 mg/dL is diagnosed as GDM.

Some complications of GDM include:

  • Maternal
    • Hypertension, preeclampsia
    • Hydramnios
    • Increased operative interventions
    • Future development of diabetes mellitus
  • Fetal and neonatal
    • Fetal macrosomia
    • Congenital anomalies
    • Metabolic abnormalities such as hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperbilirubinemia, and neonatal hypoglycemia.
    • Respiratory distress syndrome
    • Subsequent childhood and adolescent obesity

Screening is usually done at 24-28 weeks of gestation. Early diagnosis and treatment are important to prevent complications.

questions.text:
What percentage of increase in FEV1/FVC ratio represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in bronchial asthma?

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in the first minute

FVC - Forced vital capacity
questions.solution:
Reversibility of obstruction in asthma has to be demonstrated by a minimum of 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio in response to inhalation of short-acting beta-agonist (SABA).

In asthma, there is reversible bronchoconstriction leading to wheezing, breathlessness, and cough. Thus, on administering a SABA, there is bronchial relaxation and relief of symptoms. 

Asthma is generally diagnosed clinically based on symptoms alone. However, there are a number of other conditions that can be misdiagnosed as asthma such as causes of wheeze (bronchogenic carcinoma, foreign body aspiration), cough (gastroesophageal reflux, chronic bronchitis, rhinitis), and dyspnea (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pulmonary edema, or obesity). Misdiagnosis would lead to a delay in management. Thus, it is ideal that the clinical diagnosis of asthma is confirmed by pulmonary function tests. 

  • Spirometry: It is a non-invasive investigation that can be used to approximate lung volumes. This shows an obstructive pattern
    • Decreased FEV1
    • Decreased or normal FVC
    • Decreased FEV1/FVC
  • Bronchodilator reversibility: Spirometry is performed both before and after inhalation of a short-acting bronchodilator (400 mcg of β2 agonist or 160 mcg of anticholinergic). A 12% and 200 mL increase in FEV1 compared to pre-bronchodilator value is diagnostic of asthma in adults. 
  • Bronchial provocation test: Provocative stimulus (histamine, methacholine, inhaled mannitol, exercise, eucapnic hyperventilation with dry or cold air) is used to test the presence of airway hyperresponsiveness.  A fall of ≥20% in FEV1 from baseline, with a standard dose of methacholine (methacholine challenge test), is diagnostic of asthma.
  • Peak expiratory flow (PEF): PEF readings are taken twice daily for over 2 weeks. The average daily diurnal PEF variability of >10% is diagnostic of asthma in adults.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

PFT

Obstructive disease

Restrictive disease

FVC

Decreased

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1

Decreased (<80% predicted)

 Decreased

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/ increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease
  • Normal in neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

TLC: Total lung capacity

RV: Residual volume
