questions.text: Which among the following is not a component used in ACLS?
questions.solution:
Sodium bicarbonate injection is not a part of ACLS guidelines.

The drugs used in ACLS are:

  • Epinephrine/ Adrenaline
  • Amiodarone
  • Lignocaine
  • Beta-blockers

Magnesum sulphate may sometimes be included as it can be used in Torsades de pointes and hypomagnesemia

Defibrillator is also a part of ACLS.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the immunization programme?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a ten-year-old schoolchild will be administered the TT/Td vaccine according to the National Immunization Schedule.

The Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of TT vaccine with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

Scheduled to be administered at 10 and 16 years of age.

For pregnant women :

  • Td-1: early in pregnancy
  • Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1
  • Td (Booster): if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

Other options:

Option A - According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG should be given at birth or as early as possible up to 1 year of age. It provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB. A dose of 0.1 ml is administered intradermally in the left upper arm.

Option B - Measles/MR is given at 9 completed months (1st dose) and a second dose is given at 16-24 months. Measles can be given till 5 years of age. A dose of 0.5ml is administered subcutaneously in the right upper arm.

Option D - DPT vaccine is administered as a part of the pentavalent vaccine at the 6th, 10th and 14th weeks of life. DPT booster doses are administered at 16-24 months (first booster) and 5-6 years (second booster). It can be administered until 7 years of age (with booster doses). A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the anterolateral aspect of the mid-thigh. The 2nd booster dose can be administered in the upper arm.

questions.text: Hypokalemia is seen in all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
RTA 4 (hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis) is associated with aldosterone deficiency or resistance, leading to impaired potassium excretion, leading to hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis.

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which there is impaired tubular transport of H+ and/or HCO3- despite relatively well-preserved renal function. There are 4 types:

  • Type I - impaired H+ secretion (distal), leading to decreased HCO3- production
  • Type II - impaired HCO3- reabsorption (proximal)
  • Type III - carbonic anhydrase deficiency causing defects in the transport of both H+ and HCO3- (mixed)
  • Type IV - hypoaldosteronism (hyperkalemic)

The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal.

Other options:

  • RTA 1 (Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis): This condition is characterized by impaired acid secretion in the distal renal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis. Hypokalemia can occur due to the compensatory secretion of potassium to maintain electroneutrality. 

  • RTA 2 (Proximal Renal Tubular Acidosis): This condition involves impaired bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis. Hypokalemia can occur due to urinary losses of potassium.

  • Ureterosigmoidostomy: Ureterosigmoidostomy is a surgical procedure that involves connecting one or both ureters to the sigmoid colon. This procedure can lead to significant potassium and bicarbonate loss in the colon, which may result in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD with complaints of speaking nonsensical and made-up words. However, his speech is easy and fluent. His family claims his speech was fine until a few hours back. Which type of aphasia does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The patient is most likely suffering from fluent aphasia/ Wernicke's aphasia. The speech is easy and fluent but there are difficulties related to the output of language like paraphasia (substitution of similar-sounding, non-words, or incorrect words) and neologisms (non-existent words).

It is a type of aphasia that is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.

Other options: 

Option B- Broca's or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Option C- Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia. This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Option D- Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency
Wernicke's Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved
Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased
Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presented to the psychiatric OPD with low mood, loss of energy,  loss of interest in pleasurable activities, decreased sleep, and appetite for the past 2 months. What is the most appropriate treatment to be started?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette point towards major depressive disorder. SSRIs like fluoxetine are the most appropriate treatment for major depressive disorder. SSRIs should be continued for 6-9 months after complete remission of symptoms in case of a single episode of depression. 

The diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder are as follows:

A. Five or more of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period. At least one of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure.

  • Depressed mood most of the day
  • Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia)
  • Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite
  • Insomnia or hypersomnia
  • Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  • Fatigue or loss of energy
  • Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
  • Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
  • Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

B. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupa­tional, or other important areas of functioning.

C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical condition.

D. The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by schizoaf­fective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

Treatment of depression according to NICE guidelines: 

  • In recent‐onset, mild depression, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is preferred and antidepressants are not recommended.
  • Antidepressants (SSRIs) are recommended for the treatment of moderate to severe depression and for dysthymia along with CBT.
  • For treatment‐resistant depression, recommended strategies include augmentation with lithium or an antipsychotic or the addition of a second antidepressant.
  • The use of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is supported in severe and treatment-resistant depression.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives a history of ptosis and difficulty in speech and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of fatiguability that worsen with repetitive movements but resolve after rest, along with oculobulbar symptoms such as ptosis, dysarthria, and dysphagia. From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles.

It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or during late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Graves' disease, neuromyelitis optics, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increase transmission)
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission.

Treatment:

  • Anticholinesterase drugs - Pyridostigmine
  • Thymectomy
  • Immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc.
  • Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin

Other options:

Option B:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the presynaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction. It is due to the autoantibodies against the P/Q-type calcium channels at the motor nerve terminal which results in the impaired release of Ach from the presynaptic nerve terminal.

Patients present with proximal muscle weakness of the lower limbs, ptosis, and diplopia. However, symptoms might improve after brief exercise. Deep tendon reflexes are absent or reduced. They also experience autonomic dysfunction and present with dry mouth and impotence. It is most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer. 

Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows an incremental response at higher rates.

Treatment involves plasmapheresis, immunotherapy, and drugs such as 3,4-diaminopyridine (3,4-DAP) and pyridostigmine.

Option C:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is X-linked muscular dystrophy due to mutations in the dystrophin gene. It most commonly affects boys in their childhood. 

Patients initially present with proximal muscle weakness predominantly of the lower limbs. Calf muscle hypertrophy is a cardinal feature. Other features include mental retardation, cardiac failure, and myoglobinuria.

Elevated serum creatinine kinase levels and genetic testing are diagnostic of DMD.

Option D:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. It predominantly occurs in middle-aged women. Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis.

Anti-nuclear antibodies, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, anti-Smith antibodies are positive in SLE.

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: A girl presented with complaints of irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth.USG revealed multiple ovarian follicles. Which of the following would be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of irregular periods, acne, increased facial hair growth, and USG showing multiple ovarian follicles is suggestive of polycystic ovarian disease(PCOD). In PCOD, serum testosterone would be elevated.

Insulin induces LH to cause theca-cell hyperplasia and secrete androgens, testosterone, and epiandrostenedione which are converted to estrogen in the granulosa cells. Epi-androstenedione is converted in the peripheral fat to oestrone. This leads to rise in estrogen and inhibin levels. These in turn cause high LH surge. While the oestrone level increases, the oestradiol level remains normal which raises the Oestrone: Oestradiol ratio.

Endocrinological changes of PCOD:

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome 

Important clinical features of PCOS are Menstrual abnormalities (70%) - oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, obesity, hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism, acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance, and infertility.

Rotterdam criterion is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Oligo/ amenorrhoea, anovulation, infertility
  • Hirsutism/ acne
  • Ultrasound findings-

Investigations

  • Enlarged ovaries with ovarian volume will be more than 10 mm3
  • 12 or more small follicles each 2-9 mm in size placed peripherally.

Hormonal studies

  • USG is diagnostic of PCOS - it shows enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles in the periphery. It also rules out other pathologies like ovarian tumors, endometrial hyperplasia.
  • Laparoscopy (therapeutic). It reveals bilateral enlarged ovarian cysts.

The ultrasound image below shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery.

 

Management of PCOD is individualized. Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are the first-line therapy for PCOD. Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. Hirsutism and acne are managed with OCP with cyproterone acetate and topical agents such as eflornithine, clindamycin lotion 1%, erythromycin gel 2%, and isotretinoin. 

Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin and acarbose. Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical management includes laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary.

Note:

PCOS in association with diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular disease presenting in reproductive age group is known as "X syndrome".

questions.text: In a suspected murder case, the court summoned a doctor to provide his opinion and testify as a witness. This form of evidence is commonly referred to as ____?
questions.solution:
The doctor in this scenario is called an expert witness.

An expert witness is a person who is skilled in technical or scientific objects and capable of drawing opinions and conclusions from the fact observed by him or by others.  Examples: Doctor, firearm expert, fingerprinting expert, handwriting expert. (S.45 I.E.A.)

Witness: A witness is a person who gives evidence regarding facts. Sec 118 to 134 of I.E.A deals with witnesses.

Other types of witnesses: 

  • A common witness is a person who gives evidence about the facts observed by him.  The first-hand knowledge rule refers to the concept that the witness must show that he was capable of perceiving the fact by one of his own senses and that he actually observed this fact. It is applicable to all common witnesses who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him/her.

A doctor can be both a common and an expert witness.

Common witness - When he describes the wounds on the body.  

Expert witness - When he says that the wounds were antemortem or post-mortem, or they were suicidal, homicidal, or accidental, or gives an opinion regarding the cause of death.

  • A hostile witness is one who has some interest or motive for concealing part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence (Sec 191 IPC). There must be some evidence to prove that the witness has retracted from his earlier statement or is not desirous of disclosing the truth, or has exhibited an element of hostility. If a witness is declared as hostile, he can be cross-examined by the same side lawyer.

questions.text: A carpenter presents with bilateral knee pain and fluctuating swelling in the front of the knee. There is inflammation and tenderness over his knee. MRI of knee is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The fluctuating swelling in the front of the knee as well as the image, both suggest Housemaid Bursitis. 

Housemaid's knee is nothing but prepatellar bursitis and is seen in the lower half of patella and upper half of ligamentum patella. Suprapatellar bursa always communicates with the knee joint.

Lower limb major bursitis:

  • Prepatellar Bursitis (Housemaid's Knee)
  • Infrapatellar bursitis (Clergyman's knee) (option C)
  • Trochanteric Bursitis (Above hip abductor) 
    The image shows a sagittal section through the left knee joint (lateral aspect) with bursae.

Other options:

Option A: Olecranon bursitis, also known as draughtsman's elbow (or student's elbow or miner's elbow). Olecranon bursitis is a chronic inflammation of the olecranon bursa, as a result of repetitive minor injuries. It is seen in people who tend to keep their elbow rubbed against the desk. The constant friction against the olecranon bursa can lead to the development of bursitis.

Option D: Gout is characterized by an inflammatory reaction that results in the formation of gouty tophi and arthropathy when monosodium urate (MSU) crystals are deposited in the soft tissue and joints. A definitive diagnosis necessitates the microscopic identification of MSU crystals through joint fluid aspiration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. On examination, a 2x2 cm bladder mass is noted. The gross specimen image is given below. Which among the following is the ideal management?

choices.text: Intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette Guerin

questions.solution:
The given image of the specimen shows a large, fungating growth from the bladder wall involving the entire bladder with the two lobes of the prostate not being much affected. He is likely to have bladder carcinoma and should undergo transurethral resection of the bladder tumor (TURBT) for accurate staging purposes.

Given the patient's age, the presence of a bladder mass, and the need to address potential malignancy, the ideal management in this scenario would be Transurethral resection of the tumor (TURBT):

  • This procedure allows for both diagnosis and treatment of the bladder mass.
  • It is a less invasive approach, suitable for cases where the tumor is localized and hasn't invaded deeply into the bladder wall.
  • TURBT is considered the ideal management in this case because the tumor is of a size that is amenable to this approach. It is less invasive compared to radical surgery and is suitable for localized, non-invasive or early-stage bladder cancer.
  • If the tumor is found to be more aggressive or invasive after TURBT, additional treatment options can be considered.

Other options:

Intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette Guerin:

  • Intravesical BCG therapy is typically used for treating superficial (non-invasive) bladder cancer.
  • In this case, there's a noted 2x2 cm bladder mass, which suggests a localized tumor. However, the size of the tumor is significant, making it less suitable for BCG therapy, which is usually effective for smaller tumors.
  • BCG therapy is often used as a preventive measure or for smaller tumors that haven't invaded deeply into the bladder wall.

Cystoscopy with removal of tumor:

  • Cystoscopy with tumor removal can be effective for small, non-invasive tumors. However, the size of the bladder mass (2x2 cm) suggests a larger lesion.
  • If the tumor is large or invasive, a more comprehensive approach might be necessary.

Radical cystectomy:

  • Radical cystectomy involves the complete removal of the bladder and nearby structures. It is typically considered for cases of advanced bladder cancer, invasive tumors, or aggressive cancers.
  • While radical cystectomy is an effective treatment for certain situations, it is a major surgery with significant implications for the patient's quality of life. It's generally reserved for cases where the tumor has invaded deeply or is not amenable to less invasive treatments.

questions.text: A 24-year-old Rh-negative G2P1 mother was delivered by cesarean section at 37 weeks gestation. The baby is found to be Rh-positive. To access fetomaternal transfusion a Kleihaeur Betke test was done which detected 20 ml of fetal RBCs. What is the dose of anti-D that should be administered to the mother? (Assume fetal hematocrit to be 50 percent)
questions.solution:
10 µg of anti-D is required for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood or 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.Hence for 20 mL of fetal RBCs, 400 µg of anti-D should be administered.

Kleihauer–Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test for measuring the fetal red cells in the maternal circulation. The reagent used for the Kleihauer–Betke test is citric acid. It is also known as the acid elution test.

Principle: Fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A in the maternal erythrocytes.

After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as ghosts. These fetal cells are counted per 50 low-power fields. If there are 80 fetal erythrocytes in 50 low-power fields in maternal peripheral blood films, it represents a transplacental hemorrhage to the extent of 4 mL of fetal blood. 10 µg of anti-D is required for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood or 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.

Fetomaternal hemorrhage can also be quantified using flow cytometry to measure red cell size. It is unaffected by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin F or by fetal levels of hemoglobin A. Flow cytometry has been reported to be more sensitive and accurate than the Kleihaeur Betke test.

questions.text: The principle of linear accelerators is used in the production of  _____?
questions.solution:
X-rays are the most common form of radiation used in radiotherapy. They are produced from LINAC (Linear Accelerator).

A LINAC is used in radiation therapy to deliver high-energy X-rays or electrons to target specific areas of the body, typically to treat cancerous tissues. It uses microwave technology to accelerate charged particles (such as electrons) at a high speed and then directs them into a target (usually a heavy metal) to produce X-rays. These X-rays are then carefully directed at the patient's body to deliver therapeutic radiation doses to the tumor while minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissues.

Gamma rays: They are also a form of electromagnetic radiation used in medical imaging and radiation therapy, but linear accelerators are primarily associated with the production of X-rays for medical purposes, and gamma rays are usually produced in different ways.

Sources of radiation exposure:

  • Natural:
    • Cosmic rays
    • Environmental - terrestrial and atmospheric
    • Radioactive isotopes - of potassium (K-40) and carbon (C-14)
  • Man-made:
    • Medical and dental - X-rays, radioisotopes
    • Occupational exposure
    • Nuclear - radioactive fallout.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. She also has dysphagia. On examination, dental caries and enlarged cervical lymph nodes are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features of dry eyes, dry mouth and dysphagia along with cervical lymphadenopathy and dental caries are suggestive of Sjögren's syndrome. 

Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that involves lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. This manifests as xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes). It is associated with autoantibodies anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B.

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca can be diagnosed by Schirmer's test. This test measures the quantity of tears produced. Two marked strips of paper are placed between the globe and the lower eyelid and the patient is instructed to close their eyes for 5 minutes. The tears produced spread along the paper by capillary action. The distance is measured. A score of more than 10 mm is considered to be normal while that of less than 5 mm is considered deficient. 

A number of other systems can be involved as well. For example, atrophic gastritis, esophageal mucosal atrophy, and vaginal dryness. Extraglandular or systemic manifestations can also be present. These manifest as fatigue, arthritis, Raynaud's phenomenon, and myalgia. 

Diagnosis of primary Sjögren's syndrome requires the following: 

  • Eye and/or mouth dryness
  • Eye tests disclose keratoconjunctivitis sicca
  • Mouth evaluation reveals dry oral mucosa and/or
  • Presence of anti-Ro or anti-La autoantibodies

A labial (lip) biopsy is a must to confirm the diagnosis and determine the prognosis. 

Treatment of Sjögren's syndrome is directed at treating the symptoms and complications. Artificial tears can be used for dry eyes and propionic acid gel for vaginal dryness. Pilocarpine can help increase oral secretions and hydroxychloroquine can be used to treat arthritis.

questions.text:
A newly married female patient, 21 weeks pregnant, underwent a fetal USG which showed myelomeningocele of the fetus. The doctor proposed medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). Which of the following is mandatory in this case?

a. Patient's consent

b. Patient's partner's consent

c. Opinion of 1 doctor

d. Opinion of 2 doctors
questions.solution:
Only the patient/mother's consent is required for MTP; her partner's consent is not required. Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 years or if the patient is mentally ill.

2 doctors' opinion is required as the patient's gestational age is >20 weeks.

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint be lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is not a part of the immediate management in the next 24 hours?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by larvae of T. solium (cysticercosis cellulosae). Antiparasitic drugs are to be given only after glucocorticoid therapy. 

This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis.

There are various types of cysticercosis based on the site affected such as:
  • Subcutaneous nodules (asymptomatic)
  • Neurocysticercosis
  • Muscular cysticercosis
  • Ocular cysticercosis.

Neurocysticercosis is considered the second most common cause of intracranial space-occupying lesion (ICSOL) in India following tuberculosis. Its clinical features include:

  • Epilepsy
  • Raised intracranial tension
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Psychiatric disturbances
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Transient paresis
  • Behavioral disorders
  • Aphasia
  • Visual disturbances.

The below MRI of the brain shows multiple cysts containing scolices in a patient with neurocysticercosis.

questions.text: In which trimester is the quadruple test performed?
questions.solution:
Quadruple screening is a second-trimester multiple marker screening test for the detection of chromosomal anomalies like trisomy 21-Down syndrome.  

Pregnancies with Down syndrome are characterized by elevated β-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP levels.  It is performed from 15 to 21 weeks of gestation. 

The triple test findings in pregnancies with fetal Down’s syndrome are characterized by:

  • Low MSAFP (maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein) levels, approximately 0.7 MoM (multiples of median).
  • Low unconjugated estriol levels, approximately 0.8 MoM.
  • High hCG levels, approximately 2.0 MoM.

The triple test is done between 15-18 weeks for the diagnosis of Down's syndrome. 

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test (2nd trimester)
Beta HCG  Beta HCG  Beta HCG 
PAPPA  Unconjugated estriol  Unconjugated estriol 
This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG MSAFP  MSAFP 
  Serum inhibin A

First-trimester screening with biochemical analytes (↓) PAPP-A and (↑) hCG and USG measurement of NT (↑) can improve the detection rate (87%) of Down’s syndrome. For confirmation, a prenatal genetic study (CVS, amniocentesis or cordocentesis) has to be performed.

Second-trimester screening (quad screening) at 15–18 weeks: (↓) MSAFP, (↓) uE3, (↑) inhibin A and (↑) hCG can detect trisomy 21 in 85% of cases with a false-positive rate of 0.9%. When it is combined with first-trimester screening, the detection rate is increased to 95%.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented with a midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. CT confirms the diagnosis of a thyroglossal cyst. Which of the following procedures is used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for a thyroglossal cyst is the Sistrunk operation.

Thyroglossal duct cyst (TDGC)

The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. Once the gland reaches its position, where the isthmus is at the level of the second and third tracheal rings, the tract of the thyroglossal duct disappears. A thyroglossal cyst represents the persistence of this track and can be found adjacent to the midline.

Classically, swellings associated with the thyroid move with deglutition. Thyroglossal cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion, and it indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. Although they often occur in children, they may also present in adults, even as late as the 6th or 7th decade.

 

Diagnosis: 

CT scan commonly confirms the diagnosis by showing well-circumscribed lesions with homogenous fluid attenuation surrounded by a thin, enhancing rim.

FNAC may be used to exclude other causes.

Differential diagnosis: 

  • TGDC is the most common cause of a midline neck mass, followed by dermoid cysts.
  • Dermoid and sebaceous cysts are generally not tethered to underlying structures such as the hyoid bone and tend to be superficial.
  • Branchial cleft cysts are generally associated with the sinus tract or fistula, whereas TGDCs are not.
  • Lipomas are quite superficial and have ill-defined edges.

Treatment:

Sistrunk operation : This operation involves the excision of the entire thyroglossal tract, with the removal of the body of the hyoid bone and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen cecum, together with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: A woman requests for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). The doctor decides to perform a suction evacuation. Till when can this be performed?
questions.solution:
Suction and Evacuation (S&E) is best carried out between 7-12 weeks.

The various methods of termination of pregnancy are: 

Timing Medical methods Surgical methods

1st trimester

(up to 12 weeks)
  • Mifepristone
  • Mifepristone and misoprostol
  • Methotrexate and misoprostol
  • Tamoxifen and misoprostol
 		  
  • Menstrual regulation
  • Vacuum aspiration (MVA/EVA)
  • Suction evacuation and/or curettage
  • Dilatation and evacuation -
  • Rapid method
  • Slow method 

2nd trimester

(13 - 20 weeks)
  • Misoprostol
  • Mifepristone and misoprostol
  • Dinoprostone
  • Carboprost
  • Dilatation and evacuation
  • Intrauterine instillation of hyperosmotic solutions
  • Oxytocin infusion
  • Hysterotomy

questions.text: A patient presented with pain and swelling of his left arm after a fall from height. An upper arm X-ray was done. Which nerve is most likely to be injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the history and radiograph suggest a closed fracture of the shaft of the humerus. The radial nerve is commonly damaged in this condition. This is because the radial nerve follows a superficial path around the humerus and can be stretched or compressed when there is significant trauma to the upper arm. 

It manifests with wrist drop (inability to dorsiflex the wrist) and finger drop (inability to dorsiflex the digits). Numbness occurs on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand and the dorsal aspect of the radial 3 1/2 digits. 

Management of humerus shaft fractures: 

  • Conservative management using a hanging cast or U-slab for 2-3 weeks followed by functional bracing
  • Surgical fixation by compression plating, interlocking intramedullary nail, semi-flexible pins, or an external fixator is indicated in:
    • Open fractures
    • Pathological fractures
    • Unstable humeral and forearm fractures (floating elbow)
    • Radial nerve palsy

The below X-ray shows shaft of humerus fracture.

Other options:

  • The axillary nerve is most commonly injured in shoulder dislocations or fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus. 
  • The ulnar nerve is more commonly injured in conditions like elbow dislocations, fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus, or entrapment at the elbow (cubital tunnel syndrome). 
  • The median nerve is more frequently associated with injuries in the forearm or wrist, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, or with certain systemic conditions like pronator teres syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve
Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
Medial condyle of humerus  Ulnar nerve
Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve
Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve
Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve
Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

questions.text: A body was brought in for post-mortem examination, and the following can be seen. What type of wounds are these?
questions.solution:
The given image shows irregular and ragged cut wounds over the palmar surface of the hands and fingers, which is suggestive of defense wounds.

Defense wounds are the wounds that occur as a result of the victim's attempt to save himself from an injury.

It can be active or passive. Active defense wounds occur when the victim tries to grasp the weapon, while passive wounds result when the victim raises the hands, arms, or legs in an attempt to protect the eyes, head, or neck.

The morphology of the wound depends upon the type of weapon and the attack. In a sharp injury due to a single-edged weapon, a single cut may be seen on the palm or the bends of fingers. In the case of a double-edged sharp weapon, cuts are seen on both palm and fingers. The cuts are irregular in-depth and are ragged.

The defense wounds signify homicide, and in females, they often indicate sexual assault. 

Other options:

Options B and C: Antemortem and postmortem wounds are of medicolegal importance while evaluating trauma. They can be differentiated by the following features:

Feature Antemortem wounds Postmortem wounds
Edges Swollen edges with wound gapes Closely approximated with no wound gapes 
Hemorrhage Arterial type of hemorrhage Venous hemorrhage
Spurting Spurting of blood seen with firmly coagulated blood No spurts and no clotting 
Vital reaction Inflammation and repair seen No signs of inflammation and repair

Option D: Hesitation cuts are a feature of self-inflicted wounds or suicide. It typically appears as multiple, small, and superficial wounds on the skin, at the beginning of an incised wound. The common sites are the throat, wrist, and front of the chest.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with shortness of breath. He is a known case of COPD and has had similar episodes in the past, which required hospitalization. The classification according to GOLD's criteria was moderate COPD. What are the likely PFT values of the patient considering this classification?
questions.solution:
The expected pulmonary function test (PFT) values in this patient are FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 50% to 80%.

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

I

Mild

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted

II

Moderate

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

Note: FEV1/FVC is measured after the administration of atleast one short acting inhaled bronchodilator.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old pregnant woman has completed her 1st antenatal visit under the maternal and child health program (MCH). Now she is 14 weeks pregnant. How many more antenatal visits does she need to complete to fulfill the minimum requirement for antenatal visits under the MCH?

MCH- Maternal and Child Health
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, of a lady who has completed her 1st antenatal visit, should complete 3 more visits to fulfill the minimum requirement of 4 antenatal visits under MCH.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

It is advised that the woman should visit the medical officer at the PHC for an antenatal check-up during 3rd visit.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO (not MCH), is 8.

The ideal number of antenatal visits a mother should take to the antenatal clinic is:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the next month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and flank pain. History revealed that he underwent kidney stone removal 4 years back. Imaging was done and a foreign body was detected. What is the appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Cystoscopy and removal of the foreign body

questions.solution:
In a patient who has previously undergone kidney stone removal and now presents with fever, flank pain, and a foreign body detected on imaging, the most appropriate course of action is to perform a cystoscopy and remove the foreign body.

Cystoscopy is a minimally invasive procedure that involves inserting a thin, flexible tube with a cystoscope into the bladder through the urethra. It allows to visualize the interior of the bladder and urethra and can be used to directly identify and remove foreign bodies.

Leaving a foreign body inside the urinary tract can lead to complications such as infection, obstruction, or further tissue damage. Therefore, prompt removal of the foreign body through cystoscopy is the recommended approach to address the patient's symptoms and prevent potential complications.

Other options:

Option B (laparotomy and cystoscopic removal) and option C (retro-urethral approach) involve more invasive procedures and are not typically the first-line approach for foreign body removal in the urinary tract.

Option D (leave the foreign body inside) is not an appropriate choice as it could lead to ongoing symptoms and complications, as mentioned earlier. The foreign body should be removed to ensure the patient's well-being.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The parents give a history of the child ingesting 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to iron overdose, which is managed with deferoxamine (also known as desferrioxamine).

Large amounts of ferrous salts can be fatal in children. Initial symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. In severe cases, cyanosis and hyperventilation due to metabolic acidosis can develop. This can sometimes be followed by an asymptomatic phase. Later, hypoglycemia and hepatic and renal failure can develop. Pyloric stenosis and gastric scarring can develop due to its corrosive nature. Ultimately, if left untreated, the child can die.

The gastric contents can be used for an iron color test to estimate the iron concentration in plasma. As iron tablets are radiopaque, an X-ray can be used to assess the number of pills taken. Deferoxamine, an iron chelator has to be administered intramuscularly. Side effects include pruritus, wheals, rash, and anaphylaxis. 

Deferiprone and deferasirox are other oral iron chelators used to treat iron overload in thalassemia patients. 

Other options:

Option B: Activated charcoal can be used in the initial management of acetaminophen and opioid overdose. It is used for gastrointestinal decontamination to prevent further absorption of the poison.

Option C: Dimercaprol, also known as BAL (British anti-Lewisite), is used to treat arsenic, mercury poisoning, and Wilson's disease.

Option D: D-penicillamine (Cuprimine) can be used to treat scleroderma, Wilson's disease, and rheumatoid arthritis. Side effects include nephrotoxicity, hematologic derangements, and a characteristic rash that involves the neck and axillae—elastosis perforans serpiginosa. It is associated with membranous glomerulonephritis, drug-induced lupus, and myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A patient is brought in to the casualty with maxillofacial trauma after an RTA. He is unconscious with a dropping SpO2. The ER doctor decides to intubate him. What is the preferred method of securing airway for this patient?
questions.solution:
Patients with severe maxillofacial trauma are very likely to experience severe airway compromise or obstruction. Hence to maintain airway competency, intubation is necessary and in the above case, the presence of facial trauma, tracheostomy is ideal.

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

Functions: 

  1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
  2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  3. Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
  4. Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex.
  5. Allows positive pressure respiration
  6. Allows administration of anesthesia

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
    5. Bilateral abductor paralysis
    6. Congenital anomalies
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Other options:

Option A and B: Mask ventilation and LMA are not enough as the patient has severe airway compromise.

Option D:  Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in the presence of facial trauma because if there is an undiscovered fracture at the base of the skull, the tube could be forced through it and into the brain.

questions.text: The radiological imaging of choice for pheochromocytoma is ___
questions.solution:
MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor in pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. 

Clinical features of pheochromocytoma are due to the autonomic effects of excess epinephrine and norepinephrine. 

  • Weight loss is due to the increase in catecholamines which increase basal metabolism.
  • Pallor is due to alpha 1-mediated vasoconstriction. 
  • Abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting is commonly seen.

Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma requires biochemical testing followed by imaging.

  • Urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines 
  • MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor 
  • MIBG Scintigraphy and PET Scans like Ga- DOTATE, DOPA- or FDG- PET can be used for extra-adrenal tumors and metastases

Treatment of pheochromocytoma:

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment. Preoperatively, an alpha-receptor blocker (phenoxybenzamine) is given to control the effects produced by excess catecholamines. Beta-blockers are used to control tachycardia after adequate alpha blockade is achieved. This is to prevent unrestricted alpha-mediated vasoconstriction.

Following surgery, yearly follow-ups lifelong should be done.

questions.text: A male patient presented with severe abdominal pain.  On examination, the patient's BP is 80/40 mm hg, and the following finding is noted. CT abdomen is normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is that of a patient with flank ecchymosis, this is known as the Grey Turner sign and is seen in patients with acute pancreatitis.

Acute pancreatitis is a rapidly progressing inflammatory condition of the pancreas associated with significant mortality and morbidity.

The major risk factors for developing this condition are the presence of gallstones and alcohol abuse.

Patients present with moderate to severe epigastric pain associated with vomiting and loss of appetite. On examination, there is guarding and abdominal tenderness. Rarely, patients may present with Grey Turner and Cullen signs. Grey Turner sign is characterized by flank ecchymosis whereas in Cullen sign patients present with periumbilical ecchymosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which screening test will be useful to determine the etiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
In a bedridden patient presenting with sudden onset dyspnea and chest pain, there is a concern for possible pulmonary embolism (PE). Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can be suspected in this patient because of his bedridden status. The screening test used for DVT is the D-dimer measurement.

DVT of the leg is complicated by the immediate risk of pulmonary embolus and sudden death. Patients are at risk of developing a post-thrombotic limb and venous ulceration. 

Virchow's Triad: three factors important in the development of venous thrombosis. 

  • Endothelial injury (vascular Injury)
  • Hypercoagulability of blood
  • Stasia or turbulence of blood flow

The most important predisposing factor is hospital admissions for the treatment of a medical or surgical condition

Diagnosis:

D-dimer measurement: If normal, no indication for further investigation but if raised, a duplex ultrasound examination of the deep veins should be performed.

Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of DVT (Filling defects in flow and lack of compressibility indicate the presence of a thrombosis)

Ascending venography shows thrombus as a filling defect, which is now rarely required

Treatment

  • Rest, elevation of the limb, and bandaging the entire limb with a crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

questions.text: A male patient with a history of burns in his left lower limb presented to the OPD with the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of burns and the image is suggestive of a Marjolin's ulcer. It is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that grows from burns, scars, or poorly healing wounds. It presents as an indurated, non-tender ulcer with raised and everted edges with scarring in the surrounding area with marked fibrosis

The ulcer can spread to the lymph nodes when it reaches the normal skin. A wedge biopsy and MRI of the region involved confirm the diagnosis.

Management is by wide excision, for larger ulcers, amputation is done.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Postpartum blues is the most likely diagnosis in a postpartum woman with tearfulness, mood swings, and insomnia from day 4.

Postpartum blues, also known as baby blues, is a transient mood disorder characterized by sadness, tearfulness, confusion, and dysphoria. There are no suicidal thoughts or thoughts of harming the baby. These symptoms typically develop 3-5 days after delivery. They are thought to be due to hormonal changes, the stress of giving birth, and the responsibilities of motherhood. They resolve spontaneously within 10-14 days. 

Management involves reassurance, education, and support. The patient must be followed-up and assessed if symptoms persist for >2 weeks to evaluate postpartum depression.

Other options:

Option A: Postpartum depression is when the symptoms of depressed mood, anxiety, insomnia, and weight changes persist for >4 weeks as per DSM 5 or >6 weeks as per ICD 11. The onset is within 4-6 weeks post-delivery. The patient may have occasional thoughts of harming the baby and suicidal thoughts. It can persist for months to years when untreated.

Option C: Postpartum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency that usually occurs within 4 weeks after delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks after delivery (ICD 11). The predominant symptoms are hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. Psychotic symptoms such as insomnia, restlessness, labile mood, and agitation are seen. Lithium, antipsychotics, and an antidepressant is the treatment of choice.

Option D: Postpartum anxiety is not defined by DSM-5. However, some platforms might describe postpartum anxiety as excessive or severe worry after childbirth.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with the following lesions that started 2 days after he developed a fever. On examination, there are generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing multiple vesicular lesions on the trunk is suggestive of chickenpox or varicella caused by the varicella-zoster virus. 

Chickenpox

Chickenpox or varicella is caused by the varicella-zoster virus. Most infections occur before the age of 5 but can occur in older children and adults. The lesions develop in 3-5 crops and are polymorphic (present at different stages in each site). In 2–4 days, a dry crust forms leaving a shallow pink depression which, in the absence of secondary infection, heals without scarring. It is non-contagious after the lesions have crusted.

Characteristics of the rash of chickenpox:

  • Superficial
  • Pleomorphic
  • Centripetal
  • Unilocular
  • Symmetrical
  • Spares palms and soles, affects flexor surfaces and axilla
  • Rapid evolution
  • Dewdrop on Rose-petal appearance (shown in the image below)

Complications of VZV occur with disseminated varicella or with reactivation of infection. This more commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients. Complications include:

  • Bacterial infections of the skin and soft tissues
  • Pneumonia
  • Hepatitis
  • Acute cerebellar ataxia
  • Encephalitis
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
  • Sepsis
  • Shingles/Herpes Zoster: vesicular lesions are confined to the unilateral segment of the sensory nerve (dermatome). In children, the rash is mild, with complete resolution within 1-2 weeks. Unlike in adults, postherpetic neuralgia is unusual in children.

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles).

questions.text: A 20-year-old IV drug user presents with fever. On examination, his temperature is 38.5°C, and fundoscopic examination reveals spots over the fundus. Laboratory investigations show a leukocyte count of 20,000/cu mm, and blood cultures have been sent. Infective endocarditis is suspected. How many minor Duke's criteria are fulfilled in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is an intravenous drug user, with a fever of 38.5°C and spots on the fundus, indicating immunologic phenomena has 3 minor Duke's criteria.

Infective endocarditis is associated with bacterial or fungal infection of the valvular or endocardial surface of the heart. The definitive diagnosis can only be established by histological and microbiological examinations of the vegetation.

However, a diagnostic schema called, modified Duke criteria, is usually used for diagnosis. The criteria are based on clinical, laboratory, and echocardiographic findings commonly encountered in patients with endocarditis, as described below.

The diagnosis is made based on the presence of

  • Two major criteria, or
  • One major and three minor criteria, or
  • Five minor criteria.

Note: There has been a recent update in the modified Duke's criteria, which is given in the pearl below.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A female patient with a known case of thyroid malignancy was found to show high levels of serum calcitonin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Histopathology shows the presence of amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland. They are derived from the neural crest cells of the ultimobranchial bodies. 

Most of the MTCs occur sporadically. However, around a quarter of the cancers are associated with familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B.

Patients with sporadic MTC present at an older age, whereas patients with familial MTC usually present at a younger age. Features of MTC include:

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia or dyspnea if locally invaded
  • Diarrhoea due to increased intestinal motility by serotonin
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Metastasis is blood-borne
  • Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma

It is diagnosed by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin, CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.

Total thyroidectomy with central neck node dissection is the treatment of choice in MTC patients. External beam radiotherapy can be used in patients with unresectable tumors. Targeted therapy can be considered using vandetanib, sorafenib, sunitinib, and cabozantinib.

Prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutation and within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation.

Surgical management of MTC is as follows:

Extent of cancer Surgery done

MTC without LN involvement

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection (prophylactic)

MTC + level VI LN involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection (therapeutic) + Modified radical neck dissection (prophylactic)

MTC + other LNs involved

 Total thyroidectomy + Central neck dissection + Modified radical neck dissection (therapeutic)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of inducing labor?
questions.solution:
Placenta previa is an indication for cesarean delivery, not to induce labor.

Induction of labor is the process of stimulating uterine contractions for vaginal delivery by medical or surgical methods. It is indicated when the benefit to the mother or fetus outweighs the benefit of continuing the pregnancy.

Indications of induction of labor:

  • Gestational hypertension
  • Chronic hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • IUGR(intra-uterine growth restriction)
  • IUD(Intra-uterine death)
  • Oligohydramnios

Contraindications of induction of labor:

  • Contracted pelvis & CPD
  • Cord prolapse
  • Abnormally implanted placentae
  • Previous classical cesarean/ hysterotomy
  • Active genital herpes
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Malpresentation
  • Pelvic tumor & Ca cervix
  • Overdistention or complete transection of the uterus
  • Two or more previous low transverse cesarean sections

questions.text: Which of the following is helpful in predicting the virulence of a disease?
questions.solution:
The case fatality rate represents the killing power (or virulence) of the disease.

Case fatality rate = Total number of deaths due to a particular disease X 100 / Total number of cases due to the same disease

The case-fatality rate is thus the proportion of people with a particular disease who die from that disease. It is a measure of the severity of the disease, the deadliness of an outbreak, and may be used to evaluate any public health measures implemented. 

Due to changes in the agent, host, and environmental factors in different epidemics, the case fatality rate for the same disease may vary in different epidemics. It is typically used in acute infectious diseases. Eg: Food poisoning, measles, cholera, etc. 

The case-fatality rate is not a true rate, but actually a proportion. Hence, the term case-fatality ratio is often preferred.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after a RTA. On presentation, his pulse is 110/minute, RR is  18/minute and BP is 80/60 mmhg.  What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient being hemodynamically unstable after a RTA indicates a probable ongoing hemorrhage and the next step in the management is to perform an eFAST.

Cardiogenic shock, hemorrhagic shock, or pneumothorax are the most likely causes of hypotension in a trauma patient. Ultrasound evaluation using eFAST to look for pericardium, pleural cavities, and abdomen in combination with plain radiographs of the chest and pelvis will usually identify the source of the bleed. 

In patients with hypotension due to blunt trauma, the pelvis should be wrapped in a sheet for stabilization until radiography can be done. 

eFAST stands for extended FAST and incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.

Limitations of eFAST are:

  1. Operator-dependent
  2. Bowel gas and subcutaneous air distort images.
  3. Can miss diaphragm, bowel, and pancreatic injuries
  4. Unreliable for assessment of the retroperitoneum
  5. Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma
  6. May need repeating or supplementing with other investigations

FAST stands for Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma. It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid using sonography used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

Technique:

  • The patient is placed in a supine position and the following regions are scanned:
    • Subxiphoid transverse view: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
    • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

questions.text: A patient presents with a hypopigmented lesion on his back. On examination, there is a complete loss of fine touch and temperature sensation over the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a case of leprosy/ Hansen's disease. 

Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Mycobacterium leprae. It affects the skin, cutaneous and peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes. The most commonly affected peripheral nerves are the posterior tibial nerve, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves. The most commonly involved cranial nerve is the facial nerve. 

Leprosy has a long incubation period, usually ranging from 2 to 12 years. It commonly presents as an area of numbness on the skin or a visible skin lesion, which could be a hypopigmented or erythematous macule.

Ridley-Jopling classification of leprosy:

    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline tubercular (BT)
    • Borderline (BB)
    • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
    • Lepromatous (LL)
Indeterminate (IL)

One or a few hypopigmented or faintly erythematous, ill-defined to well-defined macular lesions with mild to moderate impairment of touch and/or thermal sensations. No thickening of peripheral nerves.
Borderline tuberculoid (BT)

Macular or plaque-type lesions numbering three to nine or more and asymmetrically located on any part of the body, with variable sizes and contours. Satellite lesions may be present. Loss of sensation is less intense than it is in TT lesions.

Several peripheral nerves are likely to be enlarged in an asymmetrical pattern, with sensory and motor deficits. Increased susceptibility to develop Type 1 leprosy reaction.
Tuberculoid (TT) Well-defined, hypopigmented macule or as a raised, erythematous/brown/copper-colored plaque with a well-defined edge up to three in number. 

Complete loss of fine touch and temperature sensations over the lesion.

Larger corresponding cutaneous nerves are thickened in a limited number of case
Mid-borderline (BB)

An unstable form of leprosy. Multiple plaque lesions and macular lesions; lesions are of various shapes and sizes, are bilateral, and usually occur in a more or less symmetrical. Minimal loss of sensation over the lesions.

Many nerves may be thickened, and this effect may be asymmetrical.
Borderline lepromatous (BL)

Numerous bilateral, round or oval, macular, diffusely infiltrated, erythematous, or hypopigmented lesions with moderately defined borders. Some loss of sensation may be detected, particularly over older lesions.

Widespread but asymmetrical thickening of peripheral nerves
Lepromatous (LL)

Innumerable bilateral, symmetrically distributed, diffusely indurated, erythematous, copper-colored, or skin-colored patches or plaques. There is no loss of sensation over these lesions.

Bilateral earlobe thickening and eyebrow loss occur. Coarse induration on the face gives rise to leonine facies.

Involvement of peripheral nerves occurs late and is bilateral and symmetrical, with sensory loss in a “glove-and-stocking” distribution.

Cardinal signs for the diagnosis of leprosy:

  • Characteristic skin lesions- hypopigmented or erythematous lesions with definite impairment of sensation.
  • Peripheral nerve involvement- thickening of the nerve with sensory impairment. Nerve tenderness can also be seen.
  • Detection of acid-fast bacilli in slit-skin smear, skin biopsy, or positive biopsy PCR.

The presence of two of the three signs can establish the diagnosis of leprosy. Other tests done for diagnosis of leprosy include nerve biopsy in pure neural leprosy and PGL-1 antibody in cases with low bacterial load.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of a painless lump on the lateral aspect of his left knee. The radiograph of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph and clinical vignette suggest the diagnosis of osteochondroma. 

Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that present commonly in the adolescent age group. They usually present as painless masses in long bones like the femur or humerus. They are seen as well-defined bony protuberances which may be pedunculated or sessile. Pedunculated osteochondromas point away from the joint, towards the diaphysis. The cortex and cancellous bone of osteochondroma blend with that of the host bone. MRI shows a classical cartilaginous cap.

Osteochondromas usually grow with skeletal maturity and stop once growth stops. They rarely undergo malignant transformation.

Treatment is not indicated if the lesion does not produce symptoms. Excision can be done for large lesions with local pressure effects.

Other options:

Option A: Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Option B: Chondroblastoma is a benign tumor and presents as a painful mass that causes effusion or stiffness. On x-ray, they are seen as round or oval lytic lesions in the epiphysis. The bony cortex is not breached but can appear expanded. The common sites are the ends of long bones. Microscopically, chondroblastoma consists of a sheet of chondroblasts embedded in the chondroid matrix. The calcification is often present and surrounds individual cells giving the appearance of ‘chicken wire.’

Option D: Osteoid osteoma is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone. It is common in men and most commonly occurs in the diaphysis of the femur. It is characterized by night pains relieved by medication. Nidus of osteoid osteoma is seen in the cortex and hence CT is the investigation of choice
