questions.text: A male patient comes to the outpatient clinic with dilated tortuous veins in his lower limb. Varicose veins is suspected. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for varicose veins.

Varicose veins refer to subcutaneous dilated veins of more than 3 mm in diameter. 

Investigations : 

  • Clinical examination
  • Venous duplex ultrasound which tells about:
    • The site of reflux
    • Size of vein
    • Location of perforators
    • Presence of obstruction in the deep venous system
    • Indication of pelvic source of reflux or obstruction
  • MR venography
  • Invasive procedures such as contrast venography or intravenous ultrasound.

Management of varicose veins

Incompetence Management
Great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral (SFJ) 
  • Endothermal ablation (gold standard treatment for varicose veins). It includes:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
  • Trendelenburg procedure (Flush Ligation of Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ) after ligation of 6 tributaries) ± stripping (retrogradely up to the knee, to prevent saphenous nerve injury.)     
Short saphenous vein (SSJ) and saphenopopliteal (SPJ)
  • Flush ligation of SPJ (Stripping is not done to prevent sural nerve injury)
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
Perforator 
  • Dodd and Crockett surgery - Multiple subfascial ligations
  • Subfascial endoscopic perforator surgery (SEPS) - smaller incision, so cosmetically better
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)

New treatment modalities:

  • Foam sclerotherapy - The Tessari method is a widely used method to prepare foam for sclerotherapy. Sclerosant: air ratio taken is 1:3 or 1:4.
  • Endovenous glue therapy - endoluminal application of cyanoacrylate adhesive 
  • TriVex - Transilluminated powered phlebectomy

questions.text: A patient was rushed to the emergency department after being hit in the head in a road traffic accident The patient was unconscious. CT-scan revealed an extradural hematoma. Which of the following is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
The pterion is most likely to be injured. The bone in this area is thin and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma.

Pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

It is an important structure as it overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with an acute ischemic stroke is undergoing thrombolysis with IV alteplase. He currently weighs 80 kg. What is the appropriate dose of alteplase to be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The dose of alteplase for Intravenous thrombolysis is 0.9 mg/kg. This patient weighs 80 kg, therefore the required dose would be 0.9 x 80 = 72 mg. 10% of this is given as a bolus followed by the remainder of the total dose over 1 hour. So the required initial dose is 7.2mg ∼ 8mg

This should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. 

Administration of rtPA:

  • IV access with two peripheral IV lines (avoid arterial or central line placement)
  • Review eligibility for rtPA
  • Administer 0.9 mg/kg IV (maximum 90 mg) IV -  10% as a bolus followed by the remainder of the total dose over 1 hour
  • Frequent cuff blood pressure monitoring
  • No other antithrombotic treatment for 24 h
  • If there is a decline in neurologic status or uncontrolled blood pressure, stop the infusion, give cryoprecipitate, and reimage brain emergently
  • Avoid urethral catheterization for ≥2 h

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A female patient with post partum hemorrhage has been given ergometrine and oxytocin. The bleeding still continues. Which prostaglandin derivative can be given in this situation?
questions.solution:
Carboprost, 15-methyl PGF2α can be used in a setting where both ergometrine and oxytocin have not been able to control the bleeding. 

Oxytocin is used as the first-line agent in preventing postpartum hemorrhage. When oxytocin fails or is not available, ergot derivatives can be used for second-line treatment. 

Carboprost, 15-methyl PGF2α is the drug of choice for PPH and can be used for uterine atony in a dose of 0.25 mg IM. This dose can be repeated if necessary at 15-90 min intervals, up to a maximum of eight doses.

Misoprostol: 

  • (PGE1) is useful where injectable uterotonics are not available or are not recommended.
  •  Evidence from a meta-analysis doesn't clearly favor misoprostol over other uterotonics for treating postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) or enhancing oxytocin infusion.
  • The side effect of hyperthermia with misoprostol is causes discomfort, leading to unnecessary sepsis investigations and potentially unwarranted antibiotic therapy.

Postpartum hemorrhage:

It is defined as a loss of more than 500 ml of blood after completion of the third stage of labor (in vaginal delivery).

PPH is blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract following cesarean section.

Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be, minor (<1L) or major (>1L). Major is further subdivided into moderate (1L-2L) and severe (>2L).

Types of PPH:

Primary/early PPH: Hemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Causes include

  • Atony: Primi, grand multipara, over-distended uterus, hydramnios, precipitate labor, prolonged labor, uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
  • Trauma: Instrumental deliveries, episiotomy, precipitate labor, macrosomia
  • Retained tissues: retained placenta, blood clots
  • Bleeding disorders: Sepsis, Intrauterine death, HELLP syndrome.

Secondary/ late PPH: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Causes include 

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

Resuscitative measures include

  • Airway, breathing, circulation assessment
  • A high concentration of oxygen (10–15 l/min) via a facemask 
  • Blood transfusion if clinically required
  • Fluid resuscitation with warmed fluids up to 3.5 liters, starting with up to 2 liters of crystalloids such as normal saline and ringer's lactate. Colloids can be used when there is a need for packed RBCs transfusion, until blood is arranged.

questions.text: Increased firing of _____ is responsible for the occurrence of scissoring gait.
questions.solution:
Scissoring gait is caused due to increased spasticity in the adductor muscles of the thigh, caused due to increased firing of the obturator nerve.

Scissoring gait is a type of abnormal gait pattern where the legs cross over each other with each step, resembling a scissor-like motion. This abnormality is often associated with increased firing or spasticity in the adductor muscles of the thigh, which are responsible for pulling the leg inward toward the midline of the body. The obturator nerve innervates the adductor muscles of the thigh. Increased firing or hyperactivity of the adductor muscles due to neurologic conditions can lead to scissoring gait.

Scissoring gait is a characteristic feature of cerebral palsy as shown in the GIF below-

Other Options:

  • The superior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which are involved in stabilizing the pelvis during walking. Dysfunction of these muscles might contribute to a Trendelenburg gait (characterized by the dropping of the pelvis on the opposite side of the affected gluteus medius muscle).
  • The inferior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus maximus muscle, responsible for hip extension. Dysfunction of the gluteus maximus might lead to a waddling gait.
  • The femoral nerve innervates the quadriceps muscles of the thigh, which are responsible for extending the knee. Dysfunction of the quadriceps might lead to a knee-buckling gait.

questions.text: What type of deposition is typically observed in the cerebral cortex in patients with dialysis-dementia?
questions.solution:
Amyloid ß-2 is the amyloid protein associated with dialysis-associated amyloidosis.

Dialysis-related amyloidosis

  • It is seen in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis or continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD).
  • It causes destructive osteoarthropathies, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, flexor tenosynovitis, subchondral bone cysts, and pathologic fractures.
  • The most severe complication involves amyloid ß-2 amyloid deposits destroying paravertebral ligaments and intervertebral discs, which can result in paraplegia.
  • It can also cause visceral involvement, like the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, heart, and tongue.

Treatment

  • Symptomatic relief in patients with analgesic and anti-inflammatory medication, physical and occupational therapy, and surgical procedures.
  • Renal transplantation is the treatment of choice.

Other Options:

  • Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy (CAA) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of Amyloid transthyretin protein in the walls of small and medium-sized blood vessels in the brain, specifically in the cerebral cortex and leptomeninges.
  • Amyloid beta deposition is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with aortic dissection. He continuously complains of hiccups. Which of the following nerves is most likely compressed in this case?
questions.solution:
Hiccups can be caused by irritation or stimulation of the phrenic nerve, which controls the diaphragm's movements. The structure marked as D is the phrenic nerve. 

The structures marked in the image are:

A. Right vagus nerve

B. Left vagus nerve

C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve

D. Right phrenic nerve

The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spine (C3-C5) and travels down through the chest to the diaphragm.

Aortic dissection occurs due to rupture in the inner layer of the aorta, and depending on the location of the tear, it can lead to a variety of symptoms, including pain, altered blood flow, and involvement of adjacent structures.

If the tear involves the ascending aorta or the arch of the aorta, it can potentially affect the adjacent structures, including the phrenic nerve. Irritation or compression of the phrenic nerve due to the dissection could lead to hiccups as a symptom.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation, presented with severe abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, and loss of fetal movements. On examination, her uterus is tender. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, tender uterus and loss of fetal movements in a pregnant woman points to the diagnosis of placental abruption.  

Abruptio placenta is the partial/total separation of a normally implanted placenta before delivery.

The bleeding may be either

  • Revealed - Blood dissects downwards between membranes and uterine wall to escape through the cervix. Or,
  • Concealed -Blood accumulates between the detached placenta and uterus. Or,
  • Mixed

Risk factors for abruption placenta include prior abruption history, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and pregnancy-associated hypertension. The haemorrhage into decidua basalis causes separation and compression of the placenta. This compromises fetal circulation leading to fetal distress.

 Depending upon the degree of placental abruption and its clinical effects, the cases are graded as follows:

Grade 1 Grade 2 Grade 3
Vaginal bleeding is slight Vaginal bleeding mild to moderate Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Uterus irritable, minimal tenderness

 Uterine tenderness is always present Uterine tenderness is marked.
Maternal BP and fibrinogen unaffected Maternal pulse increased, BP maintained Shock is pronounced
FHS good Fetal distress present Fetal death is the rule
Maternal shock absent Maternal shock absent Associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate


Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment over or very close to the cervical os. Vaginal bleeding is usually painless in this condition. Fetal condition is generally good until bleeding is severe which occurs in later stages. High-risk factors include multiparty, previous cesarean, or myomectomy scar in the uterus.

In preterm labour, fetal movements are not compromised. Polyhydramnios does not present with bleeding PV.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the ER after a road traffic accident. On examination, left-sided hydropneumothorax was noted. Thoracostomy was done and around 1800 ml of blood was drained in 1 hour. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Continue resuscitation for the next 6 Hours
Administer a hemostatic agent through the chest tube

questions.solution:
Given the significant blood loss (1800 ml) and the patient's critical condition, the most appropriate management in this scenario would be an emergency thoracotomy.

A thoracotomy is a surgical procedure in which an incision is made into the chest to access the thoracic cavity. It is performed in critical situations to control bleeding and repair injuries to the chest structures, including the lung and blood vessels.

In this case, the patient's condition is serious due to the combination of pneumothorax, hydrothorax, and a rapid blood loss of 1800 ml in just 1 hour. This level of bleeding suggests a severe injury to blood vessels or vital structures within the chest. Emergency thoracotomy would provide direct access to the bleeding source, allowing for immediate control of bleeding, repair of injuries, and restoration of stable conditions.

Indications for thoracotomy:

  • Initial tube thoracostomy drainage of >1000 ml (penetrating injury) or >1500 ml (blunt injury) of frank blood
  • Ongoing tube thoracostomy drainage of >200 ml/ hr for 3 consecutive hours in non-coagulopathic patients with hemothorax
  • Caked hemothorax despite the placement of two chest tubes
  • Massive air leak from chest tube with inadequate ventilation
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Tracheobronchial injury
  • Esophageal perforation

Other Options:

Option A: Thoracentesis involves the removal of fluid or air from the pleural space using a needle or catheter. However, given the severity of the situation with rapid blood loss, this procedure alone would not adequately address the underlying issues or stop the significant bleeding.

Option B: Continued resuscitation for the next 6 hours is not appropriate in this scenario due to the patient's critical condition and substantial blood loss. Immediate intervention is required to stabilize the patient's condition and address the underlying causes of the blood loss.

Option C: While hemostatic agents can be useful in certain bleeding situations, the rapid blood loss and critical nature of the presented case call for a more immediate and direct approach, such as an emergency thoracotomy, to achieve rapid control of bleeding and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A patient with a direct hernia is posted for Lichtenstein repair. Which of the following is used in the mesh?
questions.solution:
A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used.

Polypropylene is a monofilament, non-absorbable suture material. It is a propylene polymer. It is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair, ophthalmic surgery, and general surgical subcuticular skin closure. Polypropylene mesh is used for hernia repair.

A Lichtenstein mesh repair is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to fit the canal to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used for the repair of a hernia are:

  • Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament. 
  • Shouldice repair - It is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate.
  • Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) - It is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia
  • McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament.
  • Stoppa-Rives repair - It is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal space.
  • Herniotomy - It is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done

Other options:

  • Polyglactin (Vicryl)- This is an absorbable suture material and is commonly used in gut anastomoses, biliary anastomoses, and kidney and ureter surgeries.
  • Polyglycolic acid- Used for other absorbable sutures, in particular where slightly longer wound support is required.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient came with complaints of breathlessness that worsens on exertion and fatiguability for a few months. She gives a history of radiotherapy for carcinoma breast 6 months back. On examination,  bilateral lower limb pitting edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign were present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman presenting post-irradiation with progressive exertional dyspnea, bilateral lower extremity edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign is suggestive of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by diastolic dysfunction of a non-dilated ventricle with, mildly decreased contractility and ejection fraction.

Most of the cases are due to the infiltration of abnormal substances between myocytes like amyloidosis, abnormal metabolic products within myocytes as seen in hemochromatosis/Fabry's disease, or fibrotic injury like radiation/scleroderma.  

They often present with right-sided heart symptoms like edema, ascites, and abdominal discomfort. A fourth heart sound is predominately heard than a third heart sound and is often associated with atrial fibrillation. JVP shows rapid y descent and may increase with inspiration.

Kussmaul's sign is an indication of restrictive cardiomyopathy.

Kussmaul's sign is a paradoxical rise or failure in the appropriate fall of jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration. It is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis.

Normally, during inspiration, the JVP falls due to negative intrathoracic pressure. When there is an impairment in the expansion of the right ventricle or a raise in the right atrial pressure, there is a back pressure of blood in the jugular veins. This causes a paradoxical rise in the JVP during inspiration instead of a fall.

Kussmaul's sign can also be associated with

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarction
  • Advanced left ventricular systolic heart failure

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy presents with symptoms and signs of left heart failure or biventricular heart failure. Patients show cardiomegaly, and a third heart sound can be auscultated. The most frequent causes are alcoholism, myocarditis, chemotherapy, and endocrinopathies. Echocardiogram shows left ventricular dilation and dysfunction.

Option B: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy presents with dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope. Examination reveals bisferiens carotid pulse. A fourth heart sound and variable systolic murmur can be auscultated. It is an inherited autosomal disease with variable penetrance. They are caused by mutation of the gene encoding for myosin heavy chains or proteins regulating calcium handling. The echocardiogram is the diagnostic tool. Any area of left ventricle thickness more than 1.5 cm confirms the disease.

Option D: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy presents as acute anterior myocardial infarction, with acute chest pain or shortness of breath. It occurs soon after a high catecholamine surge and is seen predominantly in postmenopausal women.  Cardiac catheterization shows normal coronaries. The LV appears as a round ampulla, resembling the Japanese octopus pot called takotsubo pot. Imaging reveals apical left ventricular ballooning due to myocardial stunning. 

The image below shows a ventriculogram showing takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Identify this condition
questions.solution:
The image shows bulged, bluish lumps indicating swollen veins in the anal area. It is suggestive of hemorrhoids.

Grading of hemorrhoids:

Grades of internal haemorrhoids           Description
Grade 1 Bleeding only
Grade 2 Bleeding and protrusion, with spontaneous reduction
Grade 3 Bleeding and protrusion that require manual reduction
Grade 4 Bleeding and prolapse that cannot be reduced.

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, and smooth muscle fibers that are located in the anal canal. They can be classified into external and internal hemorrhoids according to their location.

Image below shows the endoscopic picture and diagrammatic representation of the first-degree hemorrhoids.

Image below shows the second-degree hemorrhoids.

Image below shows the third-degree hemorrhoids.

Image below shows the fourth-degree hemorrhoids.

Other options:

Condyloma acuminata are genital warts caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). They typically appear as raised, fleshy growths in the genital and anal areas. 

Genital herpes is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). It results in painful sores or blisters in the genital and anal areas. 

Condyloma lata is associated with secondary syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. Condyloma lata refers to the raised, flat, and grayish-white lesions that can occur in the anal and genital regions in secondary syphilis.

questions.text: A  female patient was provisionally diagnosed with intestinal obstruction. An emergency laparotomy was done, and the following specimen was removed. Identify the following specimen.
questions.solution:
The given specimen is that of a trichobezoar. This is a type of bezoar that forms in the stomach due to the accumulation of hair.

Trichophagia is the compulsive eating of hair associated with trichotillomania. Trichotillomania is a form of obsessive-compulsive disorder that is associated with hair pulling. In trichophagia, people also ingest the hair that they pull. 

Complications of trichotillomania include

  • Trichobezoars
  • Malnutrition
  • Intestinal obstruction

The modalities currently used in the management of trichotillomania are cognitive behavioral therapy and habit reversal training.

Other options:

  • A phytobezoar forms when undigested plant material, such as fibers from fruits and vegetables, clump together in the stomach and create a mass that can lead to gastrointestinal symptoms. 
  • Lactatobezoar is a rare type of bezoar that forms in newborns' stomachs due to the accumulation of undigested milk or formula.
  • Gangrene of the stomach can occur as a complication of conditions like gastric volvulus (twisting of the stomach), which leads to compromised blood flow to the stomach tissues.

questions.text: A male patient complains of loss of appetite and dysphagia. He lost around 6 kgs of weight in the last 3 months. He was diagnosed with esophageal cancer a few years back and was treated for it. Which of the following could be the reason of his current presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with a significant weight loss of 6 kg in just 3 months and other symptoms along with a history of esophageal carcinoma suggests a recurrence. Cancer recurrence refers to the reappearance of cancer after treatment, and it can involve the growth of new tumor cells that can lead to symptoms like weight loss, dysphagia, and other complications.

Esophageal carcinoma is more commonly seen in men. Tobacco use and alcohol are strong risk factors. Adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus are the two most common types. The squamous cell variant usually affects the upper two-thirds and the adenocarcinoma variant usually affects the lower third. The incidence of adenocarcinoma is increasing.

Clinical features include:

  • Dysphagia (most common)
  • Regurgitation
  • Vomiting
  • Odynophagia
  • Weight loss

In the advanced stage, there can be hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, horner’s syndrome, chronic spinal pain, and diaphragmatic paralysis.

Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is preferred for confirmation of diagnosis. Other investigations include barium swallow, which shows a rat-tail appearance due to irregular narrowing or ulceration. Contrast-enhanced CT and PET can be used to assess distant metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the investigation of choice to assess tumor invasion and lymph node metastasis.

TNM staging:

Primary Tumor (T)

TX

Tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of tumor

Tis

High-grade dysplasia

T1

Tumor invades the muscularis mucosa (T1a) or submucosa (T1b)

T2

Tumor invades into but not beyond the muscularis propria

T3

Tumor invades the adventitia

T4a

Tumor invades adjacent structures that are usually resectable(diaphragm and pericardium)

T4b

Tumor invades unresectable structures

Regional Lymph Nodes (N)

NX

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastasis in 1-2 regional lymph nodes

N2

Metastasis in 3-6 regional lymph nodes

N3

Metastasis in ≥7 regional lymph nodes

Distant Metastasis (M)

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text: Which of the following water-associated diseases is wrongly matched?
questions.solution:
Cholera is a water-borne disease.

Water-related diseases are classified as:

Category

Examples
Water-borne diseases

Caused by ingestion of water contaminated by human or animal feces, or urine containing pathogenic bacteria or viruses

e.g.: Cholera, typhoid, amebic and bacillary dysentery, and other diarrheal diseases
Water-washed diseases

Caused by poor personal hygiene

e.g.: Scabies; trachoma; flea-, lice- and tick-borne diseases, in addition to the majority of water-borne diseases (which are also water-washed)
Water-based diseases

Caused by parasites found in intermediate organisms living in water

e.g.: Dracunculiasis, schistosomiasis, and some other helminths.

 
Water-related vector-borne diseases 

Caused by vectors that breed in water

e.g.: Dengue, filariasis, malaria, onchocerciasis, trypanosomiasis and yellow fever

questions.text: Which among the following dementia presents with capgras syndrome?
questions.solution:
Capgras syndrome is a rare delusion of misidentification where the patient believes that someone close to him has been replaced by an imposter who looks exactly the same. Capgras syndrome along with other visual hallucinations are seen in Lewy body dementia or DLW ( Dementia with lew body). Other symptoms include depression, sleep disorders and delusions

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis. The symptoms started 3 hours ago. On examination, blood pressure is 200/100 mm of hg. CT head is shown below. Which of the following should not be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the patient with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis and CT head findings showing hyperdensity on the right side suggest an intra-parenchymal hemorrhage. Given the presence of a hemorrhagic stroke on CT scan, thrombolysis should not be done.

Thrombolysis refers to the dissolution of the intravascular clots to prevent ischemic damage and improve blood flow.

Contraindications for thrombolysis :

  • Sustained blood pressure >185/110 mmHg despite treatment 
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in the preceding 14 days
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in the preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

Indications for thrombolysis:

  • Clinical diagnosis of an acute ischemic stroke
  • The onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <4.5 hours
  • CT scan showing no hemorrhage or edema of >1/3 of MCA territory 
  • Age of the patient >18 years

Treatment of Intracranial hemorrhage:

Non-surgical: 

  • Clotting factor administration, if the patient was on blood thinners;
  • Blood pressure control to reduce the risk of more bleeding; and
  • Measuring and controlling ICP and edema (pressure on brain tissue due to clot) using osmotic therapy such as mannitol and hypertonic saline.

Surgical: 

  • Stereotactic clot aspiration
  • Craniotomy, followed by clot removal

questions.text: A female weighing 40 kg has a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L. Calculate the sodium deficit for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
The sodium deficit in this case is 400 mEq.

It is calculated by

Sodium deficit (mEq) = Total body water (TBW) x (Desired sodium concentration - Current sodium concentration)

Where,

TBW = 0.6 x body weight in kilograms, for males, and

        = 0.5 x body weight in kilograms, for females

Hence, in this case:

Sodium deficit = 0.5 x 40 x (140 - 120)

                          = 0.5. x 40 x 20 

                          = 400 mEq

Rapid sodium correction of 4–6 mEq/L should be achieved in the first 6 hours of therapy for patients with acute hyponatremia.

The rate of correction should be comparatively slow in chronic hyponatremia: <6-8 mEq/L in the first 24 h and <6 mEq/L each subsequent 24h, so as to avoid osmotic demyelination syndrome.

questions.text: What is the other name for an outlet forceps?
questions.solution:
Wrigley's forceps is an outlet forceps. It is used to provide traction force and can also be used in cesarean sections.

It is shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: Which anaesthetic scoring system is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows grading system to assess difficulty of laryngeal intubation called Mallampatti classification

It consists of 4 classes.

Grades Structures visualized
I Soft palate, fauces, entire uvula, pillars;
II Soft palate, fauces, the portion of uvula
III Soft palate, the base of uvula
IV Hard palate only

Other options

1. The Cormack and Lehane grading scale describes laryngoscopic views with grades ranging from I (the best view) to IV (the most difficult view). The grades are as follows :

Grades Structures visualized
I Entire laryngeal aperture
II Only the posterior portion of the laryngeal aperture
III Only the epiglottis
IV No visualization of the epiglottis or larynx

2. ASA physical status classification is to assess the relative risk of sedation and surgical anesthesia. it has grades from I to VI with I being healthy individual and VI being brain brain-dead patient.

3. Brodsky classification is the grading of palatine tonsil hypertrophy

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • History of snoring
  • Obesity
  • Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  • Previous head and neck radiation
  • Head and neck trauma
  • Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Down syndrome
  • Scleroderma
  • Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  • Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  • Thyromental distance <6.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  • Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  • Increased neck circumference (>17 inches in men or >16 inches in women)
  • Upper lip bite test : Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  • Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting a difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates an ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

  • Class I: soft palate, fauces, entire uvula, pillars;
  • Class II: soft palate, fauces, the portion of uvula;
  • Class III: soft palate, the base of uvula;
  • Class IV: hard palate only.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of sudden, involuntary, and uncontrollable dance-like movements. He also complains of facing difficulty with his memory. His wife says he has gotten very emotional recently.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of sudden, involuntary, and uncontrollable dance-like movements, along with cognitive and emotional symptoms, is characteristic of Huntington's disease (HD), also known as Huntington's chorea.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntington gene (chromosome 4), which results in motor, behavioral, oculomotor, and cognitive dysfunction. HD is characterized by rapid, nonpatterned, semi-purposeful, involuntary choreiform movements of limb, face, or trunk. A phenomenon referred to as anticipation is seen particularly in males, with subsequent generations having larger numbers of repeats and earlier ages of disease onset.

Tetrabenazine and deutetrabenazine are inhibitors of VMAT2 and cause presynaptic depletion of catecholamines. Deutetrabenazine is a newer form of tetrabenazine approved for the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington's disease. Deutetrabenazine takes advantage of the stronger bonds that deuterium forms with carbon (deuterated tetrabenazine). They have a longer half-life than the corresponding products of tetrabenazine metabolism.

Tetrabenazine is extensively metabolized by CYP2D6. It may cause hypotension and depression with suicidal tendencies. It can also cause Parkinsonism. Deutetrabenazine has adverse effects similar to those of tetrabenazine.

Other Options:

  • Parkinson's disease is characterized by tremors, bradykinesia (slow movement), and rigidity. It does not typically cause the dance-like choreiform movements seen in HD.
  • Friedreich ataxia is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system, causing progressive ataxia (loss of coordination). It does not typically present with choreiform movements.
  • Alzheimer's disease primarily affects memory and cognitive function, but it does not cause dance-like choreiform movements.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female complains of recurrent episodes of discomfort, pain, and a sensation of pressure behind her left eye. She has intermittent proptosis, that is reducible. Her symptoms and signs are accentuated when she bends forward. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with intermittent (on-and-off) and reducible propotosis, along with the other features most likely has orbital varices.

Orbital varices:

  • They are venous malformations of the orbit caused by vascular dysgenesis.
  • Patients usually present with non-pulsatile, intermittent, and reducible proptosis.
  • On activities such as forward bending or lowering of the head, turning the head forcefully, hyperextension of the neck, and coughing, the varices fill up, causing proptosis, and then, they regress on shifting to a non-dependent position.

Treatment:

  • Small lesions generally do not require treatment
  • Surgical excision is technically difficult and often incomplete because the lesions are friable and bleed easily; Specialized techniques such as embolization and carbon dioxide laser surgery may be helpful.

Other options:

  • Orbital hemangioma or orbital dermoid cysts will cause consistent symptoms and may not necessarily intensify with movements.
  • The patient's young age and the recurrent nature of the symptoms make metastasis less probable.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with back pain for the past 3 months. On examination, he has pallor, and gamma globulins are elevated. Liver function tests are normal. X-ray spine shows multiple lytic lesions. Which of the following cells are involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with backache for the past 3 months and multiple lytic lesions is suggestive of multiple myeloma, a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone.

Bone pain is the most common symptom of multiple myeloma. Tumor cells release osteoclast activating factors (OAFs), which increase osteoclast activity and accelerated bone destruction. Furthermore, there is suppression of osteoblast activity to form new bone. Lysis of the bone leads to hypercalcemia. Patients with multiple myeloma also have an increased susceptibility to infections because of diffuse hypogammaglobulinemia (decreased production and increased destruction) of normal antibodies. 

Other important features of multiple myeloma include: 

  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic and normochromic anemia
  • Hyperviscosity syndromes
  • Elevated ESR
  • Normal alkaline phosphatase due to suppression of osteoblast activity.
  • Serum protein electrophoresis shows the presence of monoclonal protein
  • Urinalysis shows free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence-Jones proteins)

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma include: 

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically: (CRAB features)
    • Hypercalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >2 g/dL below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET).
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥ 60%
    • Serum involved / uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater.
    • >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

Diagnostic criteria for plasma cell disorders:

Criteria Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) Smoldering multiple myeloma (asymptomatic myeloma) Multiple myeloma Non-secretory myeloma
M protein (>30g/l) No Yes Yes No
Bone marrow plasma cells (>10%) No Yes  Yes Yes

End organ damage (CRAB)

S. Calcium >11 mg/dl

Renal, S. Creatinine >2 mg/dl

Anemia, Hemoglobin <10g/dl

Lytic bone lesions

 No No Yes Yes

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after sustaining a fall onto an outstretched hand. The following cast was applied to the patient. What fracture did the patient suffer from?
questions.solution:
The cast applied to a patient in the glass-holding position is known as the scaphoid cast/glass-holding cast. It is used to treat scaphoid fractures.

To apply a scaphoid cast, the wrist is held in slight dorsiflexion and the thumb is in abduction and slight flexion, as if a glass is being held between the index finger and thumb. It extends from just below the elbow to just proximal to the metacarpal necks of the digits. On the thumb, the cast extends to just proximal to the interphalangeal joint.

Scaphoid fracture presents with pain and swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist. A fall on an outstretched hand could result in such a fracture. The fracture can be confirmed (when an x-ray does not show a fracture) if there is pain elicited in the anatomical snuff box on the radial border of the wrist.

An oblique x-ray of the wrist should be able to show a scaphoid fracture. 

Related Pearl: Plaster casts and their uses:

  Name of cast   Usage

Minerva cast

 Cervical and upper thoracic spine disease

Risser’s cast

 Scoliosis 

Turn-buckle cast

 Scoliosis 

Shoulder spica

 Shoulder immobilization 

U-slab/hanging cast

 Fracture of the humerus 

Hip spica

 Fracture of the femur

Patellar tendon bearing cast

 Fracture of tibia

Colle’s cast (hand shaking)

 Fracture lower end radius

Bachelor cast

 Developmental Dysplasia of Hip

Glass holding cast

 Fracture scaphoid

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A man was brought after he fell into a manhole and injured his perineum. He was unable to pass urine and blood was seen at the tip of the urethra. A diagnosis of bulbar urethral injury was made.  Where do you expect the urine to get collected in this case?
questions.solution:
In bulbar urethral injury, the anterior abdominal wall is one of the sites for the collection of urine.

The rupture of the urethra below the urogenital diaphragm will result in extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal pouch, penis and scrotum in males and labia majora in females, and the anterior abdominal wall.

The superficial fascia of the abdomen is divided below the umbilicus into a superficial fatty layer (fascia of Camper) and a deep membranous layer (fascia of Scarpa). Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the membranous layer of the superficial perineal fascia (Colles' fascia). 

Colles' fascia is attached to fascia lata (the deep fascia of the thigh) along the Holden's line that extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. Extravasated fluid cannot pass into the medial thigh below Holden's line due to the firm attachment of Colles' fascia to the fascia lata. 

Urethral injuries can be classified as follows:

 Type Proximal urethral injury Distal urethral injury
Site of injury
  • Prostatic urethra
  • Membranous urethra
  • Bulbar urethra
  • Penile urethra
Mechanism Secondary to pelvic fracture

Occurs due to a blow to the perineum by:

  • Straddle injury
  • Loose manhole covering
  • Gymnasium accidents
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)
  • Deep perineal hematoma
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Perineal hematoma (Butterfly hematoma)

questions.text: A 10-year-old child will have __?
questions.solution:
At the age of ten, we generally have 16 permanent and 8 temporary teeth.

Mixed dentition is a period when we see both temporary and permanent teeth. It is usually seen between 7-12 years. Generally, between these periods, the total number of teeth is always constant in number. 24 teeth are seen between 7-12 years. 

Teeth distribution during the mixed dentition period:

AGE (Years)

 Permanent Teeth Temporary teeth
9 12 12
10 16 8
11 20 4
12 24 0

questions.text: A genital examination is being performed on a patient with perineal laceration post-vaginal delivery. The tear extends into the fascia and the musculature of the perineal body but the anal sphincter muscles remain intact.  Which of the following grades of perineal laceration does this correspond to?
questions.solution:
As the tear extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body and the anal sphincter muscles remain intact, this is a second-degree perineal tear.

The perineal tear is more common in primigravida and results from over-stretching or sudden stretching of the perineum during childbirth. Trauma to the perineum can also result in perineal tears.

Clinical features include the inability to hold the flatus and feces. Soreness over the peri-anal region can be seen due to constant irritation by stool. Palpation reveals the decreased/absence of a sphincteric grip depending on the degree of tear.

All recent tears should be repaired immediately. If there is a delay of 24 hours, the repair has to be withheld and the patient has to be started on antibiotics to prevent infection. Complete perineal tears that were not repaired in the first 24 hours should be operated on between 3-6 months after delivery. In 3 months of time, any local infection that might have been present would subside, and the general condition of the patient will also improve. However, if the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms making the surgery difficult.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A six-year-old child presented with the given deformity. Identify the deformity.
questions.solution:
The image shows the cubitus valgus deformity of left elbow most probably arising as a complication of lateral condyle fracture humerus which the patient had 3 years back.

Treatment of cubitus valgus is Medial closed wedge osteotomy or lateral open wedge osteotomy.

Option A: Cubitus varus deformity is also called gunstock deformity. It happens due to the malunion of supracondylar fracture in childhood. Injury to the brachial artery is an important complication. 

Option C: Coxa vara is a hip deformity characterized by a reduced angle (less than 120 degrees) between the femoral neck and the femoral shaft.

OptionD : Coxa valga is a hip condition where the angle between the femoral neck and the femoral shaft exceeds 135 degrees.

 A combination of coxa vara in one leg and coxa valga in the other (Wind-swept deformity) is seen in scurvy
